description:
Finally got to come here as this place was on my cocktail/charcuterie list of places to try.  Sat at the bar where it was quieter than being in the seated table area.  I remember getting two cocktails, a plate of cheese and meats, and feeling super happy.  

There was still shopping to be done that day so this was what  I really needed to fuel me for the rest of my night.

It was not cheap but it was an experience worth trying.  I wouldn't mind coming back here again before a busy day of Christmas shopping.
author: Ben H L.

description:
Located in the Yelp building! Nice decor, loved the high ceilings.

The charcuterie was a great start.  Not a fan of the chicken pate, found the brussel sprouts too oily and the walnut pie was OK. Service was smug.
author: Sunil R.

description:
Meat meat and more meat. It was great!

Just went here for their NYE dinner and the experience was great. Starting off with an aperitif, we moved on to a charcuterie platter that was pretty eye opening. Awesome flavors and variations, we scarfed it down like we hadn't eaten all day. Next was salad and beef carpaccio. The salad I could have lived without but I guess it's hard to serve an entire meal of just meat. Last we had our choice of steak or pork. Most of the table went with the steak and surprisingly to all of us, the pork actually was the star of the night. The steak has a Moroccan type of spice that most of us weren't quite expecting. 

Service with our waiter, Will, was on point once we got the ball rolling.
author: Leina K.

description: Delicious charcuterie and cheese menu. Also solid wine list. I don't remember what else we ordered :)
author: Sasha B.

description:
Always a good meal here! And as always, pricey, but worth a nice occasion.

RESERVATIONS: Made online with one day's notice for a Tuesday night at 8pm for four.

THE COST: $230 before tips for 3 cocktails, 1 starter, 3 entrees, 1 dessert.

COCKTAILS
* Wildflower - 4 stars
Very well balanced for a scotch drink! I usually can't stand scotch-based drinks but really liked this one.

* Hawaiian - 3 stars
Our server recommended this for a "light, refreshing" cocktail, but this was way too strong and unfortunately, I had to send it back.

DINNER
* Salmon/Potato Fritters ($10) - 4 stars
This had a lovely crispy breading with creamy soft filling. Just don't expect too much salmon from this. 

* Pork Chop ($40) - 4.5 stars
Surprisingly delicious! The charred outer part of the meat & seasoning were the best part. 

* Beef Filet ($60) - 4 stars
Very soft, delicious cuts of meat. This just could have used a little more flavor. 

* Blackberry Mission Pie ($8) - 4.5 stars
Delicious, great crumble, and the whipped cream wasn't overly sweet.
author: Ziyan C.

description: They have great cheap lunch sandwiches to go if you work downtown and are in a hurry!
author: Lindsay L.

description:
I always thought the cocktails were the star attraction at Trou Normand. But today I discovered that their food is just as solid as their cocktail program.

My co-worker and I both had the Seared Cubano Sandwich (made with mojo roasted pork shoulder, pickles & pique, dijon & swiss cheese and a generous side of spicy dipping sauce). My colleague and I both agreed, this was one of the best Cubanos we have ever had, and totally worth the $15 price tag.

Although our food and drinks were de-lish, I do have a few minor gripes...

1) It would be nice if the sandwich came with a small salad or cole slaw or some kind of side. Hell, even a few Kettle chips would be great (especially if you're charging $15).
2) Service was a bit slow today. We ordered our food at 12:15pm, and our sandwiches didn't arrive until 12:40pm. 
3) The cocktails, although tasty, are still a bit rich for my blood. Most cocktails here will cost you between $13 - $15.

All in all, these are small quibbles. So if you're in the SOMA area and on the hunt for solid grub and strong cocktails, I'd def put Trou Normand on your radar.
author: Kevin B.

description:
Trou Normand has been on my 'places to visit' in SF since we moved here. We attempted to go for dinner one evening about a month ago, but we had no luck getting through the door without a reservation. We were finally able to have dinner there about 2 weeks ago, with 2 other friends. We sat outside on a cool August night and it was perfect. Not only is the restaurant beautiful, but the temperature was just right. 

To start we all had a round of drinks. I had a dirty martini which was delicious, however I wish they had a variety of vodkas to pick from. But they only had one type which wasn't a huge deal. Everyone else had a crafted cocktail from their menu  which they seemed to enjoy quite a bit. We all had a second and possibly third round of drinks. 

The waitress that was taking care of us was lovely, attentive and helpful. Their staff is awesome and always on their game. 

We started out by ordering A charcuterie plate for the table. The meats were delicious and savory and there were 2 different kinds of pate. They were both very tasty but one was better than the other for sure. I can't remember which. 

For our entree, my girlfriend and I had the salmon, accompanied by fresh tomatoes. It was exceptional. My boyfriend had the short rib, which was our favorite! Unfortunately they only had 1 order of short rib so he was the only one that got to enjoy it. I had a bite and loved it. I believe my other friend had some sort of lamb dish, but I could be mistaken. The food overall was above average. Every plate had different taste and was cooked to perfection. 

Overall we had an amazing time at Trou Normand. We will definitely be back, but probably when we're celebrating an occasion since it is kind of pricey. I would recommend Trou Normand to anyone who appreciates perfectly crafted meals and don't mind paying for it..
author: Tati C.

description:
Ehhh, this place was just alright.

I came here for a work happy hour, and I didn't leave too happy.  First things first, they really need to improve the Havana cocktail.  This tasted like a shot of vodka, which isn't what I'm looking for when I'm drinking with my coworkers.  I am definitely not a connoisseur when it comes to drinking but really!?  You literally served me a ~$15 cocktail...

Second, the food was expensive and not the best.  We ordered a spicy steak on the dinner menu, and it was salty at best.  I know the ingredients are fresh but it definitely didn't seem like that when it was served.  The cheese plate was also disappointing, as I had expected a good amount of cheese for the 30 something dollar plate we received... eh.

Two things I will say is that 1) their bread was great!  But then again, it was Acme bread, so when is that ever not great (the answer is never).  This could have also been toasted a little bit, so we didn't have to eat cold bread in wintry SF.  

2) The outside patio provides a very nice space for large groups, and they can enclose that space if it gets cold at night.  This made the dining experience better, but the food was definitely lacking.

Overall, I would skip if you want better cocktails and a more decent price.  This place is too much for me.
author: Jana L.

description:
For me this is a miss. Went for dinner, and it was a very cold atmosphere on a Friday night. More then half of the restaurant was empty in the back outside area. Towards 8pm we were the only ones in the restaurant. Most people came for 1 drink or a cheese plate and left.

Though the cheese and meat plate was good. I wasn't totally blown away. Especially for the price. At around $56 for 3 meats and 3 cheese, I expected more.

As for the empanadas, it was just ok. Really good chimichurri sauce; but a sauce alone wasn't enough to win me over in this case. Wouldn't recommend.

For dinner we shared the $95 30oz bone in rib eye. Lacking in flavor once again. Meat wasn't totally tender for a rib eye. Plus for presentation. Would not recommend either.

Dessert- strawberry powder donuts. This I do recommend. Sweet and delicate.

House made strawberry soda- absolutely fantastic! 

Overall for $300ish for 3 people with only 1 beer and 1 cocktail. I would skip. There are plenty of other places to blow your money on. I would take Alexander's steaks house over this any day if your looking for steak and croqueta over this place if your looking for a meat plate/tapas type of food in this area.
author: Carrie Y.

description:
At first I was hesitant to step foot in here for lunch because it looked really packed during lunch and I didn't want to wait. It gets very busy around noon with the lunch crowds. However, there's no excuse now as I work in the same building as the restaurant! I rolled in right at 11:30am when the restaurant opened and there was no wait which was great. It was a sunny day so we asked to be seated outdoors in the patio. Definitely recommended on the those warmer days.

I had the roast beef sandwich which came with a side of cole slaw. Fair warning the mustard is spicy! You'll get a great cleanse of your sinuses after eat this. I was a big fan of the flavors but it might be overpowering for others. 

Service was good and accommodating.  

I'll be back to try their charcuterie and dinner menu. I walked by the kitchen on the way to the outdoor seating area and watched them carve meats. Pretty cool that they do all of it on-site.
author: Tim G.

description:
Wowza! 

We would have had to eat 8 times a day in order to hit all our bookmarked restaurants in San Fran when we visited last.  Trou Normand was actually not even on our bookmarks but since we were in the yelp building (next door) and we were starving for lunch, of course we yelped it and this place was the closest! 

When we walked in, we were immediately greeted by the hostess who showed us to our table which was outside.  I lost my husband along the way - well, specifically he went missing where the meats are being butchered and prepped.  You have to walk through this area to get to the outside seating.  Of course I knew exactly where to find him, salivating over all the yummy raw animal flesh.

The menu is not boring and is in fact, exotic. I'm admittedly not very adventuresome but if you put a charcuterie board, I am down to try anything.  The meats and cheeses were tasty and not too funky - same with the pate - really good rich flavor without being overwhelming.  

I was a little bummed when I received the sparkling water I ordered because it had left over "muddle" of something from the previous drink. Yuck.  I brought it to their attention and it was righted real quick! In fact, the bartender himself was serving drinks and his apology negated any bad feelings about it. Sh*t happens. 

We should have sat at one of the booths inside but it was a beautiful sunny day in the city so we decided to sit outside and ended up regretting it.  Our server knew we were getting kinda miserable toward the end of our meal, and he helped hurry us out of the hot sun.

The atmosphere here is casual.  The food is top quality - they know their meats and cheeses for sure.  It had sort of a European feeling to me - sophisticated without being stuffy.  Our waitress was a delight and "got" our sense of humor.  I would definitely come back here for dinner sometime.
author: Sophie P.

description:
Bougie bijou bistro with hipster vibe. Great food, great drinks, and great service and, unlike many bars in the neighborhood, it isn't jam packed with the after work crowd. 

My wife and I popped in around 5.45, after giving up on getting a seat at Novella. We had no problem getting seated, even though it's a fairly small space. 

It's also a very interesting space, less than 15 feet wide, including the bar, but close to twice as high, with cool artwork and warm lighting that help it feel chic yet comfortable. 

It's not just the ceiling that is unusually high: the prices are up there too. So much so that I'm glad we just had the sumptuous charcuterie and not a three course meal. 

But it was fantastic food. We got the chefs choice, with three cheeses, plus salami, pate, duck terrine, and more. It was all delicious. I don't think I've had Brabander cheese since I lived in Holland 20+years and I certainly don't remember it being so good. The meats were the highlight of a great plate. But Even the bread and mustard were a cut above. And the olives were amazing. 

The cocktails are equally high quality and high priced. While I was complaining that they don't have beer on tap, my wife got me a monkey gland. A rather macho name for a small pink drink. But it was delicious. I don't know what was in it, but I'm guessing gin, absinthe, and grapefruit juice. Whatever it was, it was subtle yet strong. 

Service was unobtrusively attentive and swift. In other words: perfect.

The space was filling up when we left a little after 7. If I were to plan on dinner there I would definitely book ahead. That's definitely on our list now, though we may have to start saving for it well ahead of time.
author: Matt A C.

description:
I got swept along to Trou Normand on a Friday night with a small group of Don H.'s coworkers. I'd already eaten a normal-sized dinner, but thought I could sneak by with a cozy glass of wine, just to be social. That was before they ordered half of the freaking dinner menu and an $80 charcuterie plate. Holy sh- this place is not messing around; if you're looking for a solid place to bring a date or see where veganism goes to die, get yourself a table at Trou Normand and roll with where it takes you. 

As someone who grew up on a diet heavy on your Czech staples (kielbasa, meatballs, and head cheese), I was delighted by the cured meats, mortadella with pistachio, and (yep) the head cheese (Classic head cheese is made by boiling the head of a pig, and eating all the bits that come off of it that have congealed in the natural collagen of the head. I think they call it head 'cheese' just to screw with people that are already grossed out by the concept). The meatballs were outstanding, and the grilled pork chop had a rind of incredibly melty fat on it that put all of my week's worth of dieting to pathetic shame. 

The wine list and vegetables had a hard time holding up to the meat entrees and charcuterie - our small plate of asparagus was fine, but let's not kid ourselves here, no one was going after asparagus when they walked in the door. We had a couple bottles of French reds, which were both fine, but neither particularly complemented the food we had. Oh well. 

If you're okay with shelling out a bit of cash for a solid meal, Trou Normand is definitely worth a visit. A word from the newly wise, however: Don't go here on a full stomach, and pace yourself - 1 entree, 2 small plates and some wine are a great to start between 2 people. Enjoy the lovely ambiance and artwork, and relax. Vous allez avoir un excellent repas - bon appétit! ;-)
author: Laura B.

description:
Dinner review. Second visit.

Rabbit fig pate - 3/5
Salami arancini - 4/5
Beef leg roast - 2/5

Overall, "A-OK".
author: Mark O.

description:
Came here about two months ago for dinner on a Friday night not knowing that there was such a hype to the place. We got reservations the night of, which was actually pretty surprising since the restaurant seemed packed. We were seated outside in the garden/house area which was well-lit and really nicely decorated.

This restaurant focuses on whole animal butchery (not sure if that's the correct terminology but basically they don't waste any animal byproducts). You can tell that they put a lot of effort into setting themselves apart from other restaurants. However, I just wasn't very impressed by the food itself.

We had excellent service the entire evening, which was a pro. We ordered a plate of charcuterie (you can't choose which meats you'd like, it comes pre-set), beef short ribs, pork chop, fruit + whipped cream dessert, and a bottle of Syrah ($88 - all of the wines are quite pricey ranging to ~$200+). The charcuterie was pretty good, but the pork chop and beef short ribs were more on the dry side. Maybe we just ordered the wrong entrees? The whipped cream and fruit dessert was very fresh - I'm normally not the biggest fan of whipped cream but I couldn't stop myself from eating it. Portions were decently large, I remember not being hungry for a few hours after the meal.

The meal was pretty pricey at ~$100 per person with drinks. Overall, nothing out of the ordinary for me. It was a decent meal, but nothing very memorable or outstanding for the price.
author: Victoria L.

description:
Been wanting to come here for a while & finally made it to Trou Normad! Actually learned about this place through the booze traveler show on the Esquire channel. When I arrived I realized this place is in a gorgeous building, Yelp's home? Never been invited but rumor has it they reside here.

Walking into the bar, it's narrow & long, but with very high ceilings, a large painting of mid century lady, nice long leather chairs & tables. 

At the bar, bartender gave me some good  recommendations. When I took a peek at the menu, noticed cocktails are $$$. At ay rate, now I know. I tried the brown derby,  so I got my bourbon  & my vitamins ! Very tasty, but again pricey.

Wandered to the back, there is a larger seating area with transparent glass ceilings. I can imagine  this could be a super busy place on a sunny day or warmer eve.
author: Nawar F.

description:
Ouch.
I visit Trou Normand every few months, and often recommend them to friends and colleagues. After this last visit, I'm likely not going to.
First, the menu has changed too much. No arancini, no real vegetables. Yes, I get it...meat restaurant, but there needs to be balance especially if sharing at the table. Can only eat so much charcuterie and pork chops. 
The service, decor, and cocktails have always been on point, and continue to be so. However, the food experience this last visit left a bit to be desired. 
The accoutrements plate at $15 served two halved figs, some grapes, and fancy apple sauce. 
To top it off, we ordered the Peaches and Fromage Blanc dessert. Total miss with this dessert or the kitchen didn't execute it that evening. The plate that was served looked like bad hospital food. Fromage blanc is creamy. We were served warm large curd cottage cheese with four thin slices of peach for $8. No sauce, no seasoning. We ate the 4 slices of peach, and left the "fromage blanc".
author: Amy O.

description: Trou Normand is a gem in the city! We discovered Trou when we were looking for a wedding reception venue and ultimately chose it. The food and drinks are so unique and delicious. The chefs, staff and management are so friendly that it was a very easy decision. This place has a sophisticated but cozy vibe that lures you in. The patio area is perfect for gatherings with the citrus trees and views of the cityscape. Julia, Lauren, Maya and everyone at Trou went out of their way to make our evening so special, and we appreciate it. We had a lot of special requests and they accommodated us gracefully. ( If you have not been, definitely check out their cheese and homemade charcuterie platter, absolutely delicious!) We cannot wait to go back.
author: Yvonne S.

description:
5 Stars: the drinks! We were recommended by another bartender to visit this spot for drinks. So we came for lunch and they did not disappoint. Next time I will just come and sit at the bar and go down the list ;-)

3 Stars: the food. Nothing was bad. But nothing was great. It wasn't worth the cost. Everything seemed like something I could buy at the grocery store and easily make myself -- just presented real nicely.

My suggestion, go to the gyro spot down the street before you get here - hit the drink list - and maybe hit the gyro spot again afterwards!
author: Ross H.

description:
Went for lunch.

Meats were really nice quality, though I asked for my burger rare and got it medium... a little bummed as it was really tasty but would have been stellar if it had arrived as I ordered. Super juicy. They don't skimp on patty size.

We had the four selection charcuterie board and the cheese selection so we could have an assortment of each. At $29 per board I thought it was overpriced. Some of the cuts only had 3 or 4 pieces (and we were a party of six so we had to share thin, small slices of meat). 

But I'm really here to talk about the potatoes that come with a massive pool of heavenly aioli. I can't stop thinking about them. We ordered them as a side (an afterthought) and none of us could get enough. I don't know what they did to them. They must be twice baked or flash fried or slow roasted or some combination of those because they were so perfect. I must go back soon for them.

'Nduja arancini was delicious as well but you only get three for $12 (and they're not jumbo).

Potatoes.
author: Sam P.

description: We hosted a "wedding party" here--really more of a party to celebrate our day with friends. Julia helped me with all the arrangements, from food and beverage selection down to the details of how to get my Spotify playlist up and running. Lauren was the manager on duty for the night and was equally supportive and attentive, as was all the bar and waitstaff. Our guests had *the* best time, and raved about the charcuterie and cocktails (some dared to try every one we selected for the shortlist)! Beyond being very reasonably priced, we were given access to buyout both the front bar and back patio, which managed to fit 75+ guests comfortably. I would highly recommend Trou Normand for any large party or gathering... trying to figure out myself when we can book them next!
author: Jasmine F.

description: Great Moscow mule on some custom made ice and a great charcuterie plate. It's right underneath my office so it's super convenient. The bartenders are very accommodating and the alcohol is all top shelf. Great chill happy hour spot.
author: Justin S.

description:
I'm very familiar with the cocktail program here as it's Bar Agricole's sister property and they always come correct when it comes to spirits and libations. In fact, it's a really great spot to stop after work if you work in SOMA and I happen to work in the same building so it's super convenient. That being said, I rarely eat at Trou but, wanted to check it out. 

So, I stopped into Trou Normand for lunch last week and I gotta tell ya, it was some of the best pasta I've had in awhile. I often overlook this place as a lunch option because it's pretty pricey but, was surprised to see a reasonably priced lunch menu including the spaghetti that I ordered (I believe it was $18). The sauce was well developed, and the braised pork was heavenly. I should also note that the pasta was perfectly al dente, so props who was ever in the kitchen last Tuesday. 

My advice. Make this a lunchtime jam if you're feeling a bit fancy. I'll surely be back to try the dinner fare sometime soon!
author: Benjamin F.

description: The space is cute although the outside space seems  a bit jumbled. The staff is friendly and the presentation is lovely, however as a vegetarian it would be nice to have more options. Yes,realize this is a salmaria so duh meat heavy. It's just that given that it's 2018 and we live in SF and more and more people are trying to eat ethically with awareness to the environment, creatively having dishes that don't focus on meat seems like a no brainer.
author: elizabeth m.

description:
I've been to Trou Normand a couple of times and the great thing is that it's easy to get in without pre-planning. During the most recent visit, we woke up from an evening of drinking and wanted to grab brunch. Where could we go that is reliable, doesn't have a wait, and is not far from my place? Trou Normand immediately came to mind.

The brunch items are $17-$19 and the portion size is just enough. I had an open-faced sandwich with trout, avocado, soft-boiled egg, and arugula. It came with a side of potatoes. They season the dishes with chunky sea salt and every single part of the dish was too salty. Sea salt like that takes a bit of time to absorb into the food and the kitchen needs to taste the food after it has been out for 10-20 minutes. My friend felt the exact same way about his entree and he only ate half of it.

For a place of this caliber, I expected more. The dishes didn't have that much flavor besides extreme saltiness. We were already thirsty from being hungover and this salty brunch did not help.
author: Yi Z.

description:
It's wonderful to have restaurants close to MoMa, so that between tours/visits you can pop into a nice restaurant for lunch and, to make it more appealing, get a 20% discount for being a MoMA visitor. So, how disappointing to find that the food is somewhat odd and way over priced. 
The restaurant looks cool - loved the artwork, and even the dishes/ iced tea glasses had a modern vibe, but oh the food itself and oh, the prices. Three of our party had the fried chicken with Meyer lemon aioli. The crust was great but dark meat???? At these prices???  The marinated sardine toast and chicory salad were good, but the trout salads with preserved lime, cabbage sunchokes and gremolata were way too citrussy and tart. 
Even with the 20% discount lunch was way too expensive, especially for what we got. No interest in going g back.
author: Karne N.

description:
4.5 stars

Perfect spot for a sunny day/evening!  There's inside seating with grand yet modern decor, as well as a back patio that's kind of like a greenhouse type of setting.  FYI, if you go outside, you have to start shouting a little bit louder in your conversations.

Drinks were stellar.  I'm not usually a whiskey fan, but the one I tried was so smooth...definitely got me hooked.  I'd come back here mostly for the drinks.

Food was good (albeit overpriced for the portions in my opinion) and won't really blow you away.  One very cool thing is that they butcher their own meat right in the kitchen.
- Steak tartare:  rich and delicious
- Charcuterie board: Legit that they butcher their own meat, fresh flavors
- Salad with hazelnuts:  Really nothing special...I could have made it myself for 1/4 the price
- Short rib spaghetti:  A solid al dente noodle texture, meat was meh, and really REALLY small portions
author: Mon T.

description: What a horrible burger! I ordered it medium this week and it arrived very raw. When it returned well done it was laced with thick peppercorns that remain stuck in my throat. Not sure what the Chef is thinking but please get rid of those insane peppercorns.  I should have left when I saw the place empty. Don't eat here
author: Valerie B.

description:
10/29/16:  This is a restaurant of personality, depth, and soul.  Littered with drawings and paintings of naked women, both in standard frame but mostly curvaceously fat, complete with nipples and hair in all the right places, I must say that the owner truly understands how to excite and mesmerize.

You must start with the drinks.  The drinks would lead you into this unfamiliar world, starting strong and mature, with acute and sophisticated flavors.  The theme of the night.

The food is a dance of flavors, set on a stage of whimsical props and generously proportioned actors, unencumbered by stares and shame.  I wish the world were so revealing and so inviting to the hidden play creatures inside many of use, and for those that truly were not blessed with creativity and fun, this place is at least a beautiful representation of what you could nurture within you, to blossom someday.

And now I can only fondle memories of the fragrant house-cured bouquets of charcuterie and scintillating remnants of life...

4/5

#cocktail #drinks #bar #gourmet #american #sanfrancisco #fancy #fancyschmancy
author: Dean C.

description:
Came here for a quick dinner. MY boyfriend and I were craving for some small dishes and somewhere nearby his apartment.

There was no wait and we decided to sit outside the patio. It was very romantic and there was live music! 

We ordered:
Grilled Lamb Chops & Roast Leg: Lamb was cooked medium rare, so pretty good. the chops were OK, kind of dry. The leg was better, more fatty and tender. They sprinkled a bit too much rock salt, so the sodium was real.
Mashed Kabocha Squash brussels sprouts, gremolata: My favorite out of the whole dinner. This was a side dish, but the squash and brussels sprouts were so good, great combo with the hint of lemon!
Charcuterie: We did a combination/small for this, you can think of it as a omakase, but charcuterie. We have various of meats and a rabbit pâté. It was OK, wasn't too crazy about everything. The rabbit pâté, I personally didn't like it, my boyfriend thought it was decent. I prefer duck more.
Soft eggs with trout: Pretty good, you can't wrong with this combination

Overall, OK good, great environment and good place to sit down with friends and enjoy some drinks and small dishes!
author: Natalie L.

description:
I saw all the 4 stars and just couldn't do it because the food didn't measure up with it took a long time to receive our food with even one strangling longer then the pork chop was dry to boot.  They try to have really good service like they are on the refilling the water but lacked the communication.  We were sitting at our table and received the request if any drink orders then it all slowed down to finally they did come to take the dinner order which we had a long wait for our food - this is where it was a shame as they finally brought loaves of phenomenal bread for us with olive oil or Sierra Nevada butter (phenomenal).  They brought us more bread as we were still waiting for our food. 

At first I had hoped for the black cod but it wasn't on the menu this go around so I heard they butcher their own meat so I asked meatballs or sausage.  She said sausage (but after the fact, I wish I'd done the meatballs).  The sausage was good but really rich and overcoming so I could only eat so much of it.  Someone else had the pork chop which was disappointing as it was a dry pork chop.  The lamb shank was beautiful and I wish they noted in the menu that it should be shared as it was massive.  The lamb shank was shared but not communicating that makes me wonder if many don't order it as it's pricey but not if its shared.  

To make up for the delays, they comped us beignets and a little sparkly drink (can't remember the name).  

It's a trendy spot.  The bar drinks were interesting and really good as I had the Wildflower.  Inside was booth seating and small then you head out to the patio which was nicely covered for SF but chilly.  And someone mention communal seating where it's long tables and you may end up sharing with someone on another end.  

I think communication is an issue there as they are really trying to succeed but you waited really long not knowing; I asked to take the rest home and had no idea what came of it but she said it was on the side waiting for me which was a nice touch but I didn't know. This means like other places did it get tossed by accident?; it was a relief to receive bread which was phenomenal but it was so delayed.  There's just something missing.
author: Denise L.

description: I have to say this is my new number one place to go in San Francisco. The service is great and the food is over the top. I recommend the place. Thank you Nathan for a great dinning experience.
author: Jason S.

description: Really awesome building and outdoor patio area. It has an enclosure for cold days and space heaters. Charcuterie menu was delicious and served with inventive spreads. Highly recommend the Sofia and Lorelei cheeses. Salmon was cooked perfectly and served on a bed of tomatoes,Romano beans, and yogurt flavored with za'atar. This was a fabulous combination of flavors.
author: M N.

description:
Good, slightly expensive, but service is *really* slow. The food is 5 stars but the service is 3 stars at best. A very hip place, with exposed walls, plenty of art, and all the usual things that accompany a modern place in SF. 
Didn't get any of the charcuterie, but it looked really good. I had the fried chicken, which, even though it was a starter, was really tasty. The breading was panko or something similar and had the perfect amount of crispy juicy and salty. They were paired with beans (?) and an herby sauce. My fiancee got the persimmon toast with fresh ricotta and we split an avocado/artichoke salad. The salad was good, but they went a little high on the oil so by the end everything was just kind of swimming in a pool of oil.
The amount of time it took to get our food was excruciating, which is why the rating gets knocked down.
author: Samir K.

description: A little spendy for lunch but a beautiful patio and delicious food.
author: Victoria C.

description:
Contemporary form of serving up American cuisine!

Nice cocktails and entrees served up.

I believe gratuity is included and we tipped on top of that. Whoops.

Other than that mishap, it's a convenient spot for the after work crew near FiDi and SOMA and any other reasons in between that calls for an excuse to drink and be at leisure.
author: Tiffany D.

description:
Great ambiance, fine service, and the food was excellent.
We were taken care of from the start. 

Aperitif and then charcuterie to start us off while sipping cocktails - recommended the Jersey city!!

Meat was cooked to perfection (Denver steak) too. 

Definitely a must for for all meat lovers in SF, we will be back.
author: Patrick M.

description:
When it is a Saturday night, you're all dressed up with no particular plans, go to Trou Normand for some amazing cocktails and a great vibe. 

My fiance and I arrived here around 7PM on a Saturday night to grab some pre-dinner drinks and check this off my "go to cocktail bar spot" list I've made over the past year I've been in town. The bar boasts high ceilings, dim lights, plush leather booths to cozy up in and a cool eye-catching mural on the wall.  We were able to score the last two seats at the end of the bar by the server station and were immediately greeted by the bartender who gave us a cocktail list to look over.  

Cocktails are all priced around $13 - $17, glasses of wine are $12 - $18 and draft beer is $6 +.  We were in the mood for some nice cocktails so we started with the Daiquiri ($12) and Brown Derby ($14).  The Daiquiri was so refreshing with the mint and lime, I could have drank this down wayyyy to fast, but thankfully I only took a sip of my fiancé's and was able to enjoy my Brown Derby.  The brown derby was a nice bold bourbon drink that was simple and smooth.  Round two we went for the Single Village Fix ($14) and the Corpse Reviver ($16).  The Single Village Fix was a tart mescal drink, but very well balanced and also very drinkable.  The Corpse Reviver (I have had some other variations on this classic cocktail) was an interesting twist, my fiancé sore it tasted like apply juice (in a good way), but I felt it had some nice citrus notes and paired perfectly.

We didn't grab food here but what I saw the others at the bar getting looked good.  The service was excellent the whole time we were here.  The bartenders made it a point to chat with us, talk about our plans for the night, etc. making this a better experience than some places where they just give you a drink and walk away.  By the time we left the bar was completely full and there were a lot of people sitting down and enjoying dinner for the night.  Defiantly a place I will return for drinks and possibly a few bites to eat.
author: Kelsey B.

description:
Let me start by saying that I'm no fancy lady. It's just not my thing. However, we were heading to the SF Symphony with some friends and they chose Trou Normand as our pre-Symphony stop. I trust their judgement in all things, so away we went.

My friend had made a reservation for us, so I assumed it would be a busy place. Imagine my surprise when we were the only people there! I'm glad he made the reservation though, because within 30 minutes the little place had filled up. So Yelpers, take note: it IS a busy little place - make the reservation.

For me, the stars of the show here are the cocktails. They are strong and they are delicious. We all tried each other's drinks and enjoyed each one. I really liked the Mescal Daisy. 

For dinner, we ordered a couple charcuterie boards and an entree each. I opted for dessert for dinner which was a great choice! I had some sort of berry pie with fresh whipped cream which was next level good. The charcuterie board was generous and my husband especially loved the blue cheese stuffed figs. Our server was awesome and brought us complimentary tastes of a few items on the menu - classy move.

Overall, this was a nice place to spend a couple hours on a Friday night even if you're not especially fancy.
author: Kristen M.

description:
Curious to try a new place, we chose Trou Normand for lunch! Service was friendly, lovely, and attentive. 

We chose to share a small charcuterie board as our appetizer. We shared our main dishes with each other as well: a Pork Sausage Tartine and a Lamb Shank dish. 

The small charcuterie board allowed for four options so we chose Sofia goat cheese, salami, beef bologna, and a spicy spread I forgot the name of. It also came with a few pieces of epi bread, mustard grains, and a small side salad of what I think was parsley and fennel. Everything was great though I loved the Sofia cheese the most (and not because of the name). I'd recommend the salami over the other choices of meat we selected. 

The tartine we ordered was delicious! The toast had a great hearty crunch to it that you can only get from a good quality bread. The greens added a brightness while the sausage added a sweet and savory, juicy flavor. The avocado was creamy and really added texture while bringing all of the components of the dish together. The egg...was amazing and really added a satisfying lusciousness to the whole thing!

The lamb shank was tender though the surprising favorites were their tomatoes (bright and juicy) and the beans which added a hearty comforting feel to the dish. 

Lovely though a bit pricey, I would say this was a good experience.
author: Sofia R.

description:
Trou Normand is a truly beautiful space to have brunch in. The main dining area is well lit and the art within it,  thoughtfully curated . While the list of reasons of why I  hate San Francisco's transience is  rapidly expanding, my overall experience at brunch yesterday is not one of them. 

This restaurant prides itself with exemplary service alongside farm-to table dishes that are skillfully executed. It was pricey but I've seen worse for a lot less . The wait for the food took longer than expected but our server came over bearing "gifts" to thank us for our patience. The gifts were a generous variety of salted nuts and lemon beignets. 

Each breakfast dish was  presented as it's own unique blend of flavors highlighting the choice  protein . The charcuterie was almost too picturesque to eat . We definitely cleaned our plates ! I look forward to a visit at their sister restaurant "Bar Agricole".
author: Hannah A.

description:
It's a ghost town in downtown San Francisco on weekends, which makes a visit here for brunch a no-wait (reservations on Open Table) delicious and uncomplicated option, particularly at their 10:30 am opening time.

Trou Normand is known for its charcutterie, so the truly breakfast-y offerings are limited in favor of salads and sandwiches.  We still found plenty on the breakfast side to enjoy: a semolina pancake with peaches and berries, scrambled eggs with chevre and a decadent pork hash with potatoes and onion. Some Four Barrel coffee to round things out.

Trou Normand is around the corner from the entrance of the new SFMOMA (you can cut through the alley and you are there) so this is a well placed pre-museum brunch stop. (It also happens to be right next to Yelp HQ.) On Sundays, metered street parking here is free.

The only downside that I can see is that prices trend very steep for brunch, about $20-25 average per plate. Our best orders? The pork hash was solid and the semolina pancake was cake-like and delicious. Food, service and atmosphere here are solid.
author: Rachel H.

description: $200 for three very weak drinks (can't even get a dirty Martini), an uninteresting charcuterie plate of overlapping flavors, a three selection cheese plate (which wasn't bad) and a plate olives methinks not. Plenty of other places where the same or better quality is available at much more affordable prices. No wonder it was so dead on a Saturday night. Also, don't ask the bartender to help you take a group picture. Only two people in the picture and he cared so little that one of our eyes was closed and the other was looking away! Not cool.
author: Kimberly H.

description:
I have been coming here since they opened and have had nothing but amazing service, food and drinks. 

Come here for...

Happy Hour - Perfect bites and drinks to match. The bar is a beautiful place to sit. The patio in the back is welcoming and stunning with the lemon trees that have been planted. 

Client Lunches - Bring a client here for lunch. They will be able to find something that suits them on the broad lunch menu. Service is always fast if you're limited to one hour. 

Large groups for happy hour or dinner - Fantastic event staff! Chris will take care of you and ensure your event runs perfectly. Two weeks ago I hosted a team event in the back for about 40 people. Everyone had an amazing time! Lots of food, drinks and even a little speaker if you want to play tunes. 

Love this place, hope to see you there!
author: Alison C.

description:
Went for a birthday celebration, and enjoyed everything on the menu. The acoustics are great.  They have shared tables because they are booths, but even so we could not hear the other people at the table.  The ceilings are really tall, and the artwork plentiful.  Also great for parties.

Pros: 
The charcuterie here is really awe inspiring.  They make their own here. get the Chef's platter.  
Deviled eggs with capers and Aleppo peppers?  Wow, how could deviled eggs taste so good?    
They made sharing dishes very easy.

Cons
The pickles were overpriced and underseasoned
When a hard boiled egg cracks, it leaks out its contents.  You don't serve that deformed egg to people, OK?  That's a primary rule--put out your best or don't put out at all.
author: Benjamin H.

description:
While good food and great patio area, giving this 4 stars because the place is a bit limited and pricey for brunch. Overall it has $$ but for brunch I think it's more $$$. 

We had the pork braise and the pork eggs dish which were pretty tasty. If you're really hungry, it's probably going to not be enough food. 

Overall patio area is super nice and has some vines growing on the street side to shield the noise and pedestrians outside busy SF.
author: Melissa L.

description:
First of, I wanna say I like the ambience and interior design of this restaurant is lovely. 

Well, why did I give them a 2 stars then? 
1) Service was bad
2) Waiter insisted that he does not do individual orders (I came with a group of 12). and told me and my friend that everything had to be served at the center of the table. 
3) Food came and it was TOTALLY doable for individual orders. 
4) Waiter was literally commenting on my friends' food selection. It got my friend annoyed because "isn't it our business to order whatever we want? and why do you care about the quantity?"
5) We were there for brunch and the sun started to come out. It became really uncomfortable for people on the right side of the table, the sun was in their eyes and the whole place became SUPER WARM. I wouldn't recommend going there during the summer time... 
6) Food was only okay. We liked the charcuterie selections 
7) Mimosa sucks. I didn't know you could do badly on mimosas.
author: Kelly L.

description:
Somebody say Sunday brunch?
Yes, due to a schedule conflict, my generous cousin invited me and several family members on a rainy Sunday morning here.  I am familiar with the building as being the location of Yelp's main offices, just a few seconds up the elevator.  Mourad flanks the office entrance on the right while Trou Normand is to the left.  
Coming mid morning, I found parking on 2nd Street, just a block away.  I bumped into my cousin walking there so, when we entered, we were led to a large table under their greenhouse outdoor dining area.  It was mostly full and packed by the time we left.  
After a quick menu study and some discussion, here's what I tried:

Shared
1) Charcuterie board (https://www.yelp.com/user_local_photos?select=1-jevt-NqsrkgufRFcm9tQ&userid=saJuyv784apZzH--psHZ3Q) - My cousin chose the eight item combination for our party of six and we barely finished it.  The best I've had, but I've only tried Perbacco's.

2) Biscuit (https://www.yelp.com/user_local_photos?select=In9dVmSKbdMO4pXq_2spxw&userid=saJuyv784apZzH--psHZ3Q) - It was okay, but not must-have good in my book.  Red Lobster's will do for me...

Main
3) Pork Belly (https://www.yelp.com/user_local_photos?select=S7V9d1aJiu5v6EZQn9nCQw&userid=saJuyv784apZzH--psHZ3Q) - I thoroughly enjoyed my entrée as did my other relatives.  They had the rabbit and enjoyed mine more.

The breads, which I believe came from Acme, were delicious and fresh, perfect accompaniments to their breakfast menu whether it was the prosciutto, salumis, or just to sop up runny egg yolk from their dishes.  Our waiter was efficient and very precise in pointing our recommendations to us.  Prices were average for the area especially being a newer entry to this booming neighborhood.  I didn't know the charcuterie price, which was not cheap, until reviewing their online menu.  The diners were a mix of 20's to 30's groups outside and couples and tourists inside; if you're dining alone, you can sidle up to the bar.
Thanks to my kind and generous cousin, we enjoyed good food, service, and, of course, company.  Will be back and will keep this in mind if visiting friends are staying in or around the Financial District, Union Square, or SOMA.  Oh, and brunch works for me.
author: Mike C.

description:
Was looking for a quiet place to meet someone, have a drink and chat after work. Surprisingly hard to find in SOMA. Every place we went in was so loud, there was no way we could've had a non-yelling conversation. Trou Normand was the closest thing we found. The bar is very small and all the seats are reserved for dinner guests so we didn't think we'd be able to stay. But it was early so I told the concierge that we would only be an hour and he let us sit in one of the booths. 

I didn't feel like spending time deciding on a fancy cocktail, so I just ordered a vodka martini with olives. The waiter literally said "we don't do olives". I was so shocked that I couldn't say anything for a moment. Then I said, "what?" Its a policy. They don't have olives in the bar and they don't do olives in drinks. Dumbfounded, I meekly asked if I could have a twist, and he said yes. 

After he left, I noticed the cover of the bar menu; an illustration of an olive branch with olives on it. Hilarious! When he came back, instead of a twist, there was literally a third of a lemon peel in my tiny old-fashioned cocktail glass. While it looked over the top, it turned the whole drink into a lemon. Pretty and quite delicious!
author: Angelique L.

description:
Surprised how much I enjoyed brunch here:
*mid-century booth seating, huge, but be aware if they need to they will share your space with others, we lucked out 
*they take reservations!
*soaring ceilings with exposed pipe 
*awesome throwback speakers 
*fresh artwork 
*whimsical floral displays 
*great service once they get to you
*fantastic food, especially enjoyed the avo toast and rabbit salume, portions are petite 
*four barrel sealed the deal

Improvements: salads were overdressed, like drenched and heavily seasoned, don't love the epi baguette with the charcuterie, so chewy and dry

Love the space, food and energy.  What a great way to end the weekend!
author: Cynthia C.

description:
Had such a hard time finding this place bc it's connected to the giant building on New Montgomery. Came here on Easter evening and it was not crowded at all, which was awesome possum. We had the chef's special charcuterie plate (small), side of asparagus, pork meatloaf and aranchini. Everything was a rip-off and small portioned, so we went to super duper afterwards. 

The side of asparagus was just a dish of oily asparagus, nothing else; meatloaf dish just had a couple giant piece of meat and nothing else. Why no veggies, you know? The food, atmosphere was good but it's just so pricy!
author: Juliana P.

description:
Food wise, I've only tried their pork chop, tagliatelle, and the brown butter cake so far.

Pork chop: 3 stars
Tagliatelle: 4 stars
Cake: 2 stars (I expect it to be amazing when it costs $13 for a slice)

What stood out though, are their cocktails. I've tried a couple and they are all novel yet tasty. The interior is also pretty comfortable.

I would come back for the drinks, but prob not for the dinner at this price range.
author: Joseph L.

description: First time at this restaurant and it will be the last. The menu has no identity with items with French, Cuban, Argentinian and German preparation. It's a pricey spot for brunch so you'd expect excellent cuisine. Instead you get a highly undercooked pork belly for a $42 pork chop order. And more Sauerkraut then then sausage for a$27 dish. Total skip.
author: Dan P.

description: I had a really underwhelming experience at this restaurant.  We were taken out here for a company lunch, and I don't feel like drinking in the afternoon when I have to go back to work. Unfortunately it seems as if that's what this place caters too.  The food was not that amazing and there were no vegetarian options besides a salad and cheese.  I was really disappointed and don't recommend this place especially for the price, you could get so much more for less!
author: Jordan S.

description:
I have mixed feelings about my experience at Trou Normand.  Salami and cocktails are 2 of my very favorite things, so I'm surprised my experience at Trou Normand wasn't better.  I would probably say my experience was closer to a 3.5 for me, but since that isn't an option, I had to round down.

Pros:
Cocktails - the Monkey's Gland was perfectly balanced (and not too sweet)
Charcuterie - the salumis were superb
Chicories salad - the pomegranate seeds and hazelnuts together gave a hint of a  light peanut butter and jelly!

Cons:
Seating - our table was way too large for our group of 7.  The charcuterie and most of the entrees are for sharing, and yet we couldn't talk to those around us.  I confirmed with our server the table is normally for 10-14 people.
Temperature - our rutabaga dish came out cold
Pork chop - under seasoned? 
Dessert - tried all 3 options, and none were noteworthy
Volume - the restaurant was very loud, and we were seated so far apart at our table, it was really difficult to talk

Unfortunately, the overall experience was tainted by the seating situation.
author: Lisa P.

description: Where do I start?  The waiter forgot our appetizer.  He forgot my wine. The steaks came out room temperature.. no joke.   When I asked about it they were apologetic but they charged us for everything including all our drinks...  They did give us a nasty after dinner drink that we didn't touch it.
author: Seth T.

description:
Their charcuterie and salami selections are amazeballs! We ordered the small and it was perfect to share for 2 as an app. The rabbit salami and pork pate were the standouts. We also were surprised with a chicory salad on the house! (Thanks!)

For entree we shared the Tagliatelle. House made and perfectly al dente. 

Definitely this place is on the pricey side but good for special occasions. Highly recommend gathering a large group of friends to share the large charcuterie/salami board! It's so delish!!
author: Angela D.

description:
We stopped in for a late afternoon charcuterie and glass of wine. The mural over the bar is really great and makes for a very cool vibe. The bar is stark, with the focus being on the mural and the food/drinks. We had two glasses of wine, both were very good. It's a French varietal focused wine list with both French and California wines. 

Cheese and charcuterie were available at our time of arrival. We had a chef's choice charcuterie - $23ish for three housemade charcuteries. They were OK. The pickled carrots were a treat on the lovely plate. Plenty of bread was served. 

It was very pricey for what it is - when you can go to Mourad next door and enjoy a Michelin starred experience in a classy atmosphere for the same price. 

But, I'd come back for a craft cocktail or a drink sometime!

For the record - I see another Yelper from 2015 talking about gratuity being included in the prices. They weren't when the two of us were there, so they must have removed that tipping structure. But the prices are what she described.
author: Sarah S.

description:
I've been to this restaurant for dinner and just for drinks after work. The dinner menu is small, but very well edited so that everything on the menu looks appealing. 

My dinner companion and I split the meatballs and the tagliatelle. The meatball was delicious, an unusual texture but not in a bad way. The tagliatelle delivered and we ate it all. 

The cocktails are interesting and come in lovely stemware. 

I love the ambiance of the front bar. The booths are big and private and the lighting and sound is muted. 

I'll definitely be back when I need a convenient place near my office for a fancy drink and tasty dinner!
author: Lori W.

description:
Excellent charcuterie and dinner menu!  Small and intimate, a must try location.

Was here for a business event so luckily had an impressive multi course meal of 9 different items plus their famous charcuterie and every dish was so delicious that I'd order it in the future.
author: Cynthia C.

description:
Trou Normand is an ok brunch place -- I've definitely been to better brunch places in the city that are also not as pricey. The restaurant itself is pretty small, and you would need a reservation to guarantee that you can have a table to sit at because there are so few tables. However, the space doesn't feel small because the ceilings are very high and the door frames are also very tall and exaggerated and the two walls facing the street have long built in windows to allow in lots of natural light. 

Normally this is something I wouldn't comment on, but I found the paintings in the restaurant to be quite distracting. There were lots of paintings of naked women around the restaurant and while the artwork was tasteful, I also found it to be, well, odd. I'm not sure what aesthetic they were trying to go for with the theme they chose, but I personally wasn't a fan. 

The service was also a bit spotty, but I don't think it was our server's fault necessarily because I think he was spread thin, having to serve many tables at once. An example of the spotty service was that when I had arrived a few minutes after my group who had already been seated, the server did not provide me with a plate or cutlery even after our appetizers came out until I had asked him to do so, and even when I did, I had to ask him again for a napkin. Normally a customer shouldn't have to ask for these things -- it should be provided automatically, but again I think our server was spread too thin.

Now onto the food and drink!

APPETIZERS:

1) Apple pop tart with bourbon caramel - This was a meh dish because while the tart itself was crispy, the apples were too finely chopped and had no real flavor and the bourbon caramel was a little too bitter from the bourbon for my liking.

2) Grilled fuyu persimmons - This dish had two pieces of bread lightly toasted with butter, a slice of the creamiest goat cheese that spread like butter on the bread, and two grilled persimmons which were so incredibly juicy and being grilled really brought out the sweetness of the fruit while giving it a soft and warm texture. This was my favorite dish of the morning and I highly recommend it!

MAIN COURSE:

3) Scrambled eggs with trout - This dish was the most disappointing for me as I didn't think there was anything particularly special or amazing about it. The scrambled eggs weren't transformed in any way, and the trout and cream cheese were kept on the side of the scramble. None of the ingredients were transformed or even enhanced in any way, and I honestly felt like I could have prepared this dish on my own with items in my fridge currently. 

DRINK:

4) Supreme cocktail - This cocktail has calvados, lemon, orgeat, grenadine, and it was really delicious and complimented the meal well. The drink was semisweet and pretty strong, so I'd recommend this as a dinner drink rather than a brunch drink. 

Overall, I think if you are a meat lover, you may really enjoy this restaurant, but as someone who is a pescatarian, I expected a lot more, especially given the price point. I do not see myself coming back to Trou Normande again as there are much better brunch places out there!
author: Pooja M.

description:
I was visiting San Francisco for the weekend and had a lovely brunch experience here. We dropped in on a Sunday and were seated right away and the meal only got better from there.

We started off with a chef's selection plate and a cheese and we enjoyed all the choices. Would definitely recommend the chef's selection because all the choices were things I normally wouldn't have chosen. The highlights were the duck pâté and squid ink salami. The goat cheese was a bit strong by itself, but I loved mixing it with the dates we had on the plate. 

And, the entrees were great too! I was trying to find the exact names of what we had, but apparently the menus change daily according to their website (that means I definitely have to go back!!). But I had braised short ribs with butternut squash, and my boyfriend had their burger. Both were amazing. And, would recommend the sleepyhead for their cocktails. 

Definitely want to come back if I'm in San Francisco again.
author: Victoria L.

description:
Tip is no longer included with the bill, but the menu price remains the same.

The overpriced hotdog is now a "sausage sandwich" They changed the name. Way too much dijon mustard and onions.

$53  lunch for two and no alcohol included this time. I left hungry.

Probably won't be back.
author: Angelica C.

description:
Lovely modern, rustic dining atmosphere. Came here for brunch on a Saturday morning and ordered the small Charcuterie Board Chef's Selection. This one came with four selections of 1) the Duck Pate which had figs and rosemary 2) the Pork Pate which had fennel and thyme 3) the Cayenne Salame with garlic and white wine and 4) 19 MONTH PROSCIUTTO. I also added the Brunet cheese, which is pasteurized goat's milk from Italy. Got to have some cheese with a Charcuterie Board!

What I loved was the Duck Pate, the 19 MONTH PROSCIUTTO and the Brunet cheese. All were delicious. The Brunet cheese was so soft, rich and buttery, and I loved that they serve local Acme Bread! The downside was that they only gave me two pieces of bread to start (Which really equated to ONE piece of bread cut diagonally in half.) so I ordered four more pieces of bread thinking it was part of the Charcuterie Board. Turns out it's $2 for two pieces so I ended up paying an extra $4 for BREAD. I was so upset. Anyway, I really did not like the Pork Pate at all. The texture was a bit stiffer in a weird way and stringy. The Cayenne Salame was alright, nothing special. 

Overall, Trou doesn't have much in terms of selection for brunch. Hence - The three stars. I think that's why I ended up ordering a Charcuterie Board. There seems to be a lot more selection during lunch and dinner so I would love to come back and try Trou once more. Also, they change their menu daily, so perhaps I just went on a random off day.
author: Debra T.

description:
We came here on a Sunday for my wife's birthday. The parking around the area is very scarce. Also, on the day  we went to the restaurant, there was an event happening nearby. This made the parking situation even worse. We spent half an hour trying to get parking and missed our reservation. The hotel staff were very understanding and seated us immediately as we came there.

From the drinks menu we selected a bottle of wine. The server took our order and then returned after a while saying that they don't have it in stock. This was disappointing. We then ordered from the mixed drinks section. The old fashioned cognac was really good.

Then we ordered from the starters menu. The three cheese selection was heavenly and the chicken wings was juicy and well marinated.

From the entree menu I would recommend the scrambled eggs and the lamb and ram sausage. The portions are a little small and a little pricey, but you pay for a wonderful experience.
author: Kiran S.

description:
I don't think overall the price justifies the value. Be aware of the extra SF healthy tax of 5%. 

The food and drinks were decent but plate size portions were small. Bread was not served without asking. I had a large group of people there last night and expected better service. 

I do recommend the charcuterie, pork shank, and king salmon to share. 

Also - no need to make a reservation the place definitely had space on a Saturday night.
author: Yayan L.

description:
Charcuterie was really a hit at this place! We got the small chef's selection for group of 3 and it was a good sized appetizer. The bread comes with the platter was really good too and you can keep asking for refills. We also tried meatballs, black cod and cauliflower dishes and they are all good. Too full to try the dessert.
I was told that they change menu daily so a lot of items I saw on yelp are not available. I was hoping to try the pasta dishes. I guess I would need to come back.
Side note though, the place has communal seatings but the seats are very nice plush leather booths. So it's probably not a good place for date but it was nice for friend gathering.
author: Mengyuan G.

description:
I love the vibe at Trou Normand, as well as the rich selection of pate and salami! Come in and get a drink at the bar... or sit down and get dinner. 

We had the small combination board, and the chef selection for the day was pork pate, beef salame, ciccioli and bierwurst (but we swapped this for dried pancetta). It was amazing. Loved the entire platter and I wish we could have more! My favorite was the pancetta and ciccioli. It also came with mustard, pork consommé and fennel salad which were great sides.

The tagliatelle was also cooked perfectly. The pasta was cooked just to the right texture, slightly aldente, and the dish was seasoned perfectly. Also, just the right amount of bolognese :)

Will definitely come back again, highly recommended!

PS. 20% tip is included in the price and the service is excellent!
author: Christina N.

description:
I visited Trou Normand twice: once for happy hour staying for dinner. I returned with a large group in early March.

Food: The charcuterie program is the best! The empanadas are amazing. They really like to use salt. Our group dining included really great salads, but it is a really meat-heavy menu, so vegetarians beware.  The menu is trying to be Euro-inspired California cuisine. The server kept talking about the owner's passion for telling stories with their menus, but this story needs a good editor. 

Also... the thing about open kitchens is, if you have a chef that's going to be screaming at the servers and cooks, it's on display for everyone to see/hear. I know chefs typically have big egos, but this food is good not great.  He could stand to eat a slice of humble pie, (maybe he could add it to their lame 2 item dessert menu).

Drinks: Their specialty cocktails include ingredients I had never seen before, but it was all great. When I came in with a big group the service was still fast considering the recipes they're working with. 

Service: We had the same server, Cat, on both occasions. She was friendly and knowledgeable about the food and beverages. She spoke well about their butcher/charcuterie, and general mission of the restaurant. Her service was attentive and warm. We could tell she is really passionate about their ingredients, and really won me over to why I should be happy to pay as much as I did for ok food. 

All in all it's pricey place, but if you like to support slow food and their whole mission of using the whole animal etc, the service and drinks are good and it's definitely worth a visit.
author: Nb P.

description:
The service- slow and disengaged.
The appetizers- OK but very average. We ordered the squash blossoms, a cheese board, and head cheese. Nothing stood out but we ate it because we were hungry.
The Ribeye- I've eaten a LOT of steak in my lifetime and this may have been the worst ribeye I have ever tasted. I am highly convinced that it was previously frozen and sitting in back of the freezer for a while, and they popped it in the microwave to cook it. It arrived rubbery, tasteless, and was completely cold. When we notified our server that it was cold, she took our plate, and popped it back in the microwave and then it became a warm version of a terrible steak. 50 bucks down the drain. Face palm.
The cocktails- very nice which is why I didn't give it 1 star.
Overall, nice for a drink after work but unless you want to shell out money for bad, bland food, go somewhere else for dinner.
author: Sarah C.

description:
SALUMÍ
I am hangry, Bruncharch.
[Salumí dances the dance of the $78 Charcuteries.]

BRUNCHOD
Ah! nomderful! nomderful!
You see that it has Iced Tea for me, your diner.
Come near, Salumí, come near, that I may eat me my reward.
Ah! I tip the dancers accidentally. I will tip thee doubly.
I will eat thee Scrambled Eggs thy soul desireth.
What wouldst thou listen? Beach Boys.

SALUMÍ
[Kneeling.]
I would that they presently bring me on a wood boarder....

BRUNCHOD
[Laughing.]
On a wood boarder? Surely yes, on a wood boarder.
It is charming, is it not?
What is it you would have on a wood boarder,
O sweet and fair Salumí, you who are fairer than all the dishes of Soma?
What would you have them bring thee on a wood boarder?
Tell me. Whatsoever it may be, they shall serve it you.
My treasures belong to thee. What is it, Salumí?

SALUMÍ
[Rising.]
The board of Charcuteraan.


- excerpt, Hogscar Wilde. "Salumí". 1891
author: Dan B.

description: Good wine and cocktails, great atmosphere and very nicely bartenders. Would definitely come again.
author: Penny B.

description:
Just happened to walk in to try when going out for dinner. The service was very attentive, constantly filling water and available to explain any dishes. The restaurant itself is rather dimly lit, especially the restrooms!

Started out with charcuterie and cheese board. I wasn't very impressed by any of the cheeses but did appreciate the pickled grapes. Several of the meat was very tasty, including the ham and goat.

For entrees I picked and the broccoli was AMAZING. I tried the charred eggplant but it was limp and the texture not too appealing. The steak someone else ordered looked to be perfectly cooked.

We ended up trying all the desserts. The winner was definitely walnut pie or strawberries and cream. The others were rather underwhelming. The peach and blackberry pie was far too sweet and expected more tartness.

Overall it was an interesting try but probably would not return.
author: Cindy R.

description:
Love this place!! The "outdoor" patio is awesome; I highly recommend getting seated there. There's also a group table right in front of the kitchen that looks like a good time.

The cocktails are pretty good, very brandy focused. I got the Supreme and it was delicious. Don't get outraged by the prices, they all include tip, so it's actually a great deal!

The food was pretty good. We got the salumi, melon salad, summer squash, braised green beans, and pork meatballs. All the veggie dishes were delicious!

Definitely coming back to try the charcuterie and more drinks!
author: Sherry L.

description:
This place is a winner, on several levels.  Staff is knowledgeable and friendly, service is excellent. 
Food is fresh, seasonal and well prepared.  The ambiance is pleasing and fresh. Plus, they keep great hours...open nearly all the time.  Love it and will frequent it.
author: Candace C.

description:
I've been here twice now.  Once for a weekend brunch and once for a special event (cocktails + appetizers).  Both times, the service was exceptional.  The drinks were interesting, well crafted and strong. 

Now the food. Arancini - Delicious, although hot at first, so be careful about diving right in.  Burger - huge, messy, juicy, and ultimately not manageable.  I got through about half of it and had to give up.  Next time, I'll have try to something else, but will definitely be back.
author: Denis S.

description:
Let me preface this review by saying that I have worked as a server in the past. Actually I worked just down the block from Trou Normad. 

We were a party of 7 on Sunday after the SF marathon. We were seated almost immediately. Tables were filled, but it wasn't exceptionally busy. Guests looked like they were mosey-ing brunch at a very comfortable pace (and so were the staff).

The food was mediocre.  I ordered "crispy duck confit" and got a whole golden potato, 2 poached eggs, on a light "sleeping bag" of what appeared to be collard greens, 5-6 shreds of duck, all slathered in hollandaise sauce for $23. Safe to say I was disappointed. The flavor doesn't make up for it. Also, it took 30-45 minutes for the food to come to the table. The kitchen was slow, which was fine, but the service.... 

The service was horrendous and, dare I say, discriminatory. I hate to pull this card, but after a day I can't shake the feeling. We were a table of multi-racial individuals from age 25-45. 

We were seated and then promptly ignored without greeting or water for at least 15 min. At which point we had to flag down a server.  Our server had the most blazè attitude toward our table. I ordered an iced tea and asked for a pitcher/jug of water for the table considering the water glasses were basically shot glasses and I saw other tables have a large container of communal water. I asked twice, she said yes, nothing came. When she did refill our glasses, I asked for a larger glass, which she filled halfway. I know we're in a drought but come on this is ridiculous. We sat for long periods(30-45 min) with empty glasses at the table. 

I get it, a table of 7 sucks. But it's Sunday brunch, it happens all the time. Our server barely did the minimum: took our order, brought our order. 

We saw a surprising increased response rate from the server when our seemingly white male friend was at the table for a portion of the meal.  When he left, the service deteriorated. 

Our check took forever to come. It took 15-20 minutes to then process our payment, which was NOT hard because it was cash and a card.  

We were in Trou Normad for a total of 3 hours from start to finish. And this is after the marathon, which some of us ran, we inhaled that food.  Most of the time we were waiting. 

This is the first time , ever, I did not leave a tip.  And I frequent hole-in-the-wall Asian restaurants with horrendous service.  But at least at those establishments we got what we asked for at least. Again, I was a server before. I get that servers NEED to be tipped at least 15% for bare minimum service. This place was awful. I don't understand the good reviews it received.
author: Stephanie L.

description: Incredible charcuterie, I believe made on prem.  Awesome drinks, that are awfully sneaky.
author: Mike U.

description: I came here twice for late lunch and both times were on point. The drinks were fantastic (according to my husband) and the charcuterie meats are so good that I don't know how to explain it with words. Depending on what you get, the meats could melt in your mouth or perfectly spiced/salted. The cooked seafood dishes we had were also perfectly done and seasoned (fried smelts and lightly fried squid). Will be back to visit the establishment every time we visit the bay area.
author: Lina W.

description:
Top notch. We had a reservation, but when we arrived, there was no where for us to sit besides being shoved in the back room. While we waited for one of the booths to leave, the hostess was so cute and apologetic and offered us champagne while we waited. Now THAT is service. 

The food was definitely different and our party shared a number of different things on the menu. I cannot remember everything that we ordered, but it was all very good. However, nothing really stuck out as blowing my mind, but I think it was just my personal palette.  The charcuterie board was on point and probably my favorite part. I don't even know what all was on it, but I liked it! If you come, be sure to start off with that.

My only complaint is that the menu is very small. They definitely specialize in the food they offer, but I need just a tad more variety.
author: Jenna H.

description: Their house made salumi are insane, and the wine selection is fabulous. I love coming here for lunch and sitting outside on the patio, but the bar is nice too if you're just in for a quick drink.
author: Caroline F.

description:
Pork Chop get the PORK CHOP! One of the best pork grilled pork chops I've ever had. Comes close to NOPA's porkchop.

Drinks are great and strong.

Service awesome everyone was courteous. Definitely will come back next time I'm in San Francisco.
author: J B.

description:
As a group we shared the large charcuterie. The items were hit or miss, some with salumi tasting mediocre or not significantly better than store bought. Favorites were the mortadella and rabbit and pork pâtés. We also split three cheese boards which were good but not worth the price tag. Three selections - some hard goat cheeses and a softer sheep's milk which was my favorite. Came with some grapes and olive oil seasoned frisée.

New York Strip Steak - The servers said it was a rare treat, locally sourced from pastured grass fed cows not usually sold wholesale. They said they're the only restaurant that gets their cows and butcher them in house. Weighing in at 12-13 oz, simply plated and unadorned with sides, I was completely satisfied just having half. Tasted like a high quality cut of meat, buttery with great char and flavor but just a touch overdone. Port jus a perfect savory and lightly sweet sauce to round it out. Shelling Beans were a nice side dish crunchy, though pricey for what you get. Service was excellent and very attentive. I wasn't blown away but I would definitely come back again to try the other mains.
author: Truc N.

description:
Paid a visit to Trou Normand last night for cocktails and late night bites. 

This place is upscale and trendy without trying too hard. Love the different seating areas ...front bar area is lined with plush leather couches. There is a communal farm table as you make your way to the back. Then you have the greenhouse patio with heat lamps....my fave! 

Charcuterie: so many delicious options. Plated with the best quality pork and meat. The accompanying mustard is flavorful but not too spicy. 

Arancini: I know this is a popular side but I don't really see the hype in it. Good but not that good. 

Tagliatelle: pasta was al dente. Meat sauce on point. 

Overall this place is great for HH and good for large groups!
author: Emily Y.

description: Trou Normand is a fantastic gem in the sad sea that is SOMA off-peak dining. They are obsessive about their charcuterie, and they have a fabulous, heated, glass encased patio in a garden in the back. My dream brunch, happy hour, or dinner, is sitting on Trou Normand's patio, sipping on a dry rose, and ordering the largest "Chef's choice" charcuterie platter the menu offers. They bring out over a dozen cured meats, most if not all made in their kitchen, and delicious bread, butter, and mustard. You then sit there making tiny sandwiches and basking in the glow of your self-admiration for making the excellent choice to dine there.
author: Tasha D.

description:
I had resos but they were unnecessary as it was empty on a Friday evening. The food and drinks were great. Dined here in 2016 so the menu has since changed but the pork ragu was delicious. Like... scraping the sauce out of the dish delicious. 

However, unlike the food, I found the service to be a little cold and bland. If the service and hospitality matched the level of care they put into their menu. I'm just not a fan of the bougie hipster vibe. 

Verdict: No matter how good the food is, if I don't feel welcome or comfortable, you can't really expect me to come back.
author: Erin M.

description:
First off, who doesn't love a good charcuterie?  And there's is exceptional.  And made in house.  But it's not enough to offset the negatives I felt about the place.  Namely:

1.  We were in the back area that seems to be about 65% of their seating.  It was cold and obscenely noisy.  The acoustics in the space create that competitive environment where everyone needs to talk over the noise to be heard, thus spiraling the problem.

2.  It's prices are just too much not to be offended by.  I get that the dining scene is going this way.  I eat out often in great places.  So it's not just that I'm getting old.  But it's starting to get insulting.  Don't tell me food costs are that much higher on this block of SF alone.

3.  The community tables.  If I wanted to dine with strangers, where you simply can not avoid hearing every single word of their conversation...

Service was solid.  Food was very good.  If those three objections don't bother you, give it a try.
author: James S.

description:
I understand why some SF businesses, including Trou, are instituting a new pricing structure where tip is already included in menu items. I waited tables and bartended for over a decade and I get it. 

Front of the house. 
Back of the house. 
Living wage. 
The struggle is real. 

Having 20% included on everything doesn't bother me at all - in fact, I think it'll save me some scratch since I'm an over-tipper given my history in the service industry... but what does bother me is that the prices at Trou, a place my colleagues and I were regulars at, definitely went up closer to 30% than 20% with that change and the service 100% went down. 

If it was just the 20% I'd let it slide because good or meh service, I still tip at least that always, but 30% more for everything + now you're being taxed on the tip amount as well + it feels like the servers/bartenders now just know they've got theirs coming so there's no point in really offering much service, which was absolutely the case on what was possibly our last visit. 

If I'm paying $18 for a single glass of wine on the low end of the menu, I'd like just a little bit of cordialness to come with it.  

I know everyone loves their cheese and meat plates and all that jazz but I just think they're aight. We would come a lot for lunch and you'll see a pretty typical SF style menu with carefully portioned ala carte plates and privileged lunchtime diner prices, which is expected for a place with as nice of digs as Trou has, but I've never been wowed and I've never left feeling like my food was more than a healthy snack.
