I mean, now I don't really have to worry about it because we've pretty much been priced out of coming here... at least when I know Mourad is just 2 doors down, with what is now very similar beverage price points and much higher service quality... and gladly tip on top of it. 

Also, to be fair, I've never had their breakfast sandwich (which I've heard is on another level) so maybe I'll be singing a different tune some other time, but with so many places to spend what little extra payola is left after rent, I just don't think I can justify the jump in price and drop in customer care. 

It's still a beautiful place and if you're going on an expendable business account or are taking home one of those SF tech money paychecks it's a totally decent place, I'm just in a bracket where I need my money to work harder than that.
author: Candice G.

description:
This place is such a rip off, I can't even believe it.

We ordered the small charcuterie plate.  It was good, but it didn't make my eyes roll back in my head.   At $24, it was the most reasonably priced item that we ordered.

Beef Shank Tagliatelle - $28!??!   Seriously?   It was a relatively small portion of pasta, and although tasty, it was really nothing inventive enough to justify that price point.   To put things in perspective, when were at Octavia last month, we ordered an exquisite papardelle appetizer that was totally unique and delicious....unlike anything I had ever had before.   It was only $14.   But that was only an appetizer, you say?   Yeah, about that......at Trou Normand they were offering a side of Chard for $15.......FUCKING CHARD!!!!!   

The most mind boggling thing was the price on the cocktails.   They were clocking in an average of $15 and trust me when I say, this was NOT, in any capacity, a cocktail that was worth $15.  I would have been happy paying 10 or 11 tops for that.   It was a gin cocktail that was good, but there wasn't anything about it that was special.   I feel like I have had that cocktail 15 times before.

They seated us out in this enclosed patio area that is actually pretty cool.   It is a glass enclosed greenhouse like space and you can see all of the buildings above you.  The problem is that the sides flap open and it was really windy.   There are heaters inside over all of the tables, but unfortunately the one above ours was not working.   We asked to be seated elsewhere or even down at the end of the the table (tables are all communal) where there was heat.   The waitress came back and gave us some bullshit about how every other table was reserved and that there was nothing that she could do.......there was literally one other table that had people at it in this area.   Apparently at this establishment, walk-ins are seen as lesser-thans in relation to those who have made a reservation, and are, thus, the ones deserving of being subjected to the cold.

I just read in another review that they had switched to the gratuity included model in their pricing.   If that is the case, then I am even more infuriated, as this was not clearly worded on the menu, was not told to us by the server and, when the bill arrived, there was also no mention of this, and there was even a line to enter the tip amount, which we did.

So yeah, take your money elsewhere.   It will go a lot further and you will enjoy yourself a lot more.
author: Christian C.

description: One of my favorite hidden spots in SF especially for brunch and their amazing outdoor patio. Service was great this time (thanks Anemone and Dominic!) and we sat for hours drinking and ordering various bites. Their cocktails are top notch and we thought everything we tasted was perfect and refreshing. Loved everything about our Sunday afternoon here and can't wait to return!
author: Semuteh F.

description:
Had lunch here! The food is quite amazing! I especially like the pesto spaghetti. So fresh! The lamb sandwich is okay. Too salty for me. But the baked Potato is awesome. Kind of Salty but really tasty.

I definitely recommend having lunch here. It's not very crowded at all. You can also enjoy the sunshine in the patio or backyard.
author: Jie C.

description: Went there with my boyfriend and we enjoyed our time there. The service was really good and the food was amazing. I also really like the restaurant's environment. Have been recommending my girl friends to go there. :)
author: Clare L.

description:
Wife and I went yesterday for charcuterie, wine and drinks. 
The service was knowledgeable on spirits and the food, very kind as well and worked together as a team. 
The charcuterie was phenomenal!! I must go back for the large platter. Worth every penny. 
The cocktails and wine were very tasty as well. Definitely going back. One of our new favorites in SF.
author: Nick M.

description: What an amazing treat! One of the best meals I have had in a long time. The Simplicity and cleanness of the food is amazing. Thank you so much to all the staff they are so friendly and attentive. I just wish we were closer I would be here every night! Hats off to Chef Seth you're amazing!
author: Lulu's F.

description:
Oh, Trou Normand. How many times have I come by for lunch or happy hour without a reservation? Too many to count!

If you're lucky, there will be a seat at the bar or table outside on the covered heated patio. For the most part the hostess will do her best to accommodate, but be warned that they get very busy come 6 pm and might not be able to honor your request.

What I love? 
The wine
Cheese plate
Papperdelle pasta
That breakfast sandwich

Plus the ambiance is incredibly sexy! The perfect spot for a romantic tryst to begin.
author: Abby S.

description:
Came here early on a Saturday night and sat in the covered outdoor seating area in the back.  If was really pleasant, especially since it was still light out.  We started with the small salumi/charcuterie plate, which had rabbit pate, ciccioli, lamb salame, and lonza.  Everything was great, but the ciccioli was the highlight, with intense porky flavor.  I got the lamb for my main, which was perfectly cooked, although the sauce was not especially exciting.  Compared to the other mains I saw at other tables (and their prices on the menu), it seemed like the lamb was certainly the best value.

Overall, the charcuterie was awesome, and the atmosphere was great. Next time we come, we might just get a larger charcuterie plate and supplement it with a few sides instead of getting any entrees.
author: Simon L.

description:
Ambiance and service was very good but be aware, this is no fast meal. I think this was intentional since they didn't need the table and it was obvious my group of girlfriends were having a great time chatting over brunch. It was so nice that they didn't rush us. We were there for 3 hours!

A little over priced but it's downtown and such a beautiful restaurant! Hope they keep doing brunch. 

Get coffee and the sandwich!
author: Meredith M.

description:
Trou Normand was exactly what I thought it would be, but my beau wanted to go so I obliged. I had reservations and we were seated promptly when we arrived. All of the seating in communal, which I don't like but I don't hate. In some places it is fine, but here it was really annoying. We sat between two other couples.

The menu is interesting. They have some entrees and small plates but what they're known for is their charcuterie and salumi board. We got one and it was good, but nothing to rave about. We were squished between two couples at this table with a giant cutting board full of charcuterie. It would have been impossible to eat an entree as we were too squished in between the couple to move. The servers kept putting bottles of water on the table, which is great, but it took up too much room. It was really awkward.

The drinks were really good. The owners are the same as Bar Agricole so it has a similar feel and similarly inspired menu.

The service was strange. We ordered our drinks from one guy and literally 30 seconds later a woman came to take our drink order. At one point we ordered the arancini and we were corrected that it's pronounced "air-an-chee-nee." Ok, dude, I get it. That's not how the Italians pronounce it, but we're not Italian. You knew what we were talking about.

Luckily I had a feeling what the Norman Hole would be like so I made a reservation at Dirty Habit right after and enjoyed myself immensely there.
author: Ryan L.

description:
Cocktails:  5 stars well made bourbon drinks - but if you like fruity drinks it might not be your spot

Ambience:  5 stars - cool spot for Friday night but should try make reservation before 8pm.  We had a 9:30 reservation so by the time around 10ish restaurant was half empty.  Also a lot of the tables are communal tables. Patios will be open in the next week or so.

Food: 

I really enjoyed the pork belly dish ($10) - 3 good pieces of pork belly perfectly crispy skin and nice five spices flavor well balanced by grape fruit and some arugula. 5 stars

Main dishes are a la carte (no sides). Pork Chop ($24 - 5 stars) was grilled perfectly, slightly pink in the middle, super juicy.  Sole ($19 - 4 stars)  was a whole fish with cream sauce, de-bone table-side if requested.  Was very fresh.  We ordered a side vegetable which was nicely prepared ($9).

Overall - 4.5 stars.  Great service. Good vibe.  I would go back to order cocktails eat at the bar and order the pork chop and appetizers.
author: Edmond T.

description:
We always order the charcuterie plate (try head cheese and any pate), small for two people and medium for four or more. Include some salumi (try coppa and any salami) and that is half your meal. I highly suggest doing that route as some of the main dishes were uneven - good but not wow. For the prices I was hoping most if not all the dishes would be great, but it may be due to my personal taste/palate.

The drinks here are strong and I suggest starting the night here. Cognac and I were never good friends back in the day, and my preferred drinks (Old-Fashioned and Manhattan) are cognac based. Other drinks I've tried were strong as well. Do not make it the final stop unless you have a liver of steel.

I like the space and decor, simple, and somewhat intimate so don't expect to bring a large group. The communal table in the back is good only if you're dining with one other person. Ironically, sitting there felt more private than sitting in the main dining area.
author: Peter L.

description:
Me:  Hey, have you been to Trou Normand?  
Friend: No, but I've been wanting to go there.
Me:  I'm gonna go for lunch one day.  You're not invited.
Friend: Fine, I'll just go and sit at the table next to you.

Fast forward to today, 2/17/16.  I decided to go on a lunch date with...myself!  Yup, ditched the friend to enjoy a nice meal, solo.  Got here around 12:00pm, had an option to sit at the bar or patio but since I was alone, bar it is.

CHARCUTERIE BOARD chef's selection, SM (4 selections)- Pate, Ciccioli, Pork Bologna, and a salumi but not sure what its called.  All very good selections but my favorite was the Ciccioli.  
SAINT ROSE raw sheep's milk, California- Meat and cheese go together and so I had to order something from the cheese menu.  I requested for something not too firm but not too soft.  This was good to nibble on and it really went well with the meats.
ARANCINI- Fried risotto ball filled with cheese and either tomato sauce and/or meat?  I'm not sure but hey, its a fried rice ball, can't go wrong with that.

TROU NORMAND house calvados or Armagnac- Since this was my first time dining here, the bartender/server presented me with this drink on the house.  It was realllly strong and since I had to go back to work, not to mention I get flushed red when I drink, I was unable to finish it.

Overall, good meal, excellent service.  I spent a whopping $68 for this meal and for that, I don't think I would come back.  Prices are high but hey, sometimes you just gotta treat yo self.
author: Linda N.

description:
Trou Normand is a perfect spot for professionals and friends or couples alike. I've taken clients from out of town here and they loved it- from the ambiance to the food!

Had the PORK burger, a glass of wine, and of course some charcuterie/cheeses to share a few months ago when dining here with my client. I LOVED the burger ($20) I had most recently. Apparently they do change the meat they use to make the burger all the time. Sometimes its lamb or beef or pork.

The service was on point for us- we were well taken care of.

Albeit the cuisine been different than neighboring Mourad, I think Trou Normand's prices are pretty standard for this area. For lunch, they have a couple of more affordable options - from $6-13 Starters, 18-$20 Burger/Sandwich Mains, $16-$36 for the other entrees. For dinner, it's simply the starters ($6-13) or main entrees with more protein choices ($20-$36). Their Charcuterie and Cheese Menu isn't cheap but the Salumi/Charcuterie is made in house and everything is amazing. You can either order a la carte and it costs $10-13/each, or there's a special - $26 / $52 CHARCUTERIE BOARD chef's selection .

I do want to return on a date night here- it seems like it would be a fun spot for a evening out on the town! High ceilings, minimalist look, open spaces, and contemporary feel - I love the vibe here.
author: Veronica S.

description:
I love Trou Normand, the charcuterie is tops in SF.  Whether you decide to perch at the art-deco bar with a brandy-cocktail or relax on the heated back patio with a glass of wine and charcuterie plate, you can't go wrong.

40 types of salumi and charcuterie served with fresh baguette, yums!

The wine list is fairly extensive, indexing toward old-world reds, particularly Italian reds.  

Trou Normand is open all day so I typically to stop in mid-afternoon for a drink and snack.
author: Lance W.

description: I ordered the roast beef sandwich. I did not know how to present my feelings for this sandwich. Soooooooo great! I loved the sauce they put in the sandwich. It was a little bit spicy, but i enjoyed tasting it. And also, the fried potato was good. I was not a big fan of fried potato, but I finished most of fried potato for this plate. Perfect match!
author: Zhiqi L.

description: Good but a bit pricy. Enjoyed the charcuterie plate. Husband liked his expensive Cubano sandwich. My pasta was really salty and didn't have much substance to it.
author: Jen K.

description:
I've visited Trou Normand a few times during the couple of years that they've been in business on the ground floor of my office building, the beautiful Pacific Telephone Building at 140 New Montgomery. Like any new business, they've done their share of experimenting with different menus, schedules, and prices. Fortunately, I've always found the quality to be very high, and the experience to be pleasant.

For breakfast, I used to really enjoy the pistachio croissants that they used to sell (it was a while back now), but they discontinued those. Now they only open for brunch on weekends (never been).

For lunch, they have a few great sandwiches, which originally were very reasonably-priced ($10-12), but are now in the $18-20 range. Whatever the price, they're delicious, and the ambience is nice. I don't necessarily blame them for charging higher prices, but it does make me less likely to visit for lunch.

For dinner (or just drinks), the bartenders know what they're doing, and the cocktails prove it. The dishes at dinner are also excellent, and the space is really special. It makes for a good date night.
author: Andrew M.

description:
I regrettably built Trou Norman up in my head to a somewhat God-like status of charcuterie, which I blame on being starry-eyed from certain bloggers boasting of fantastic meals here. Don't get me wrong, I DID have a nice experience here, just not as magical as I dreamed. My fault, really.

THE HIGHLIGHTS.
+ Cozy little joint with a bunch of cozy leather booths for your dining pleasure (sized for both small and large groups)
+ Extensive, impressive house-made charcuterie menu
+ Solid, hand-crafted cocktails (and a knowledgeable bar keep, as well!)
~ Pricey for what you end up getting, but considering the amount of time, energy, and sourcing that goes into each menu item, it makes sense
~ Reservations can be difficult to get for prime hours, as well as parking, but you should still try your luck anyways!

I don't dream of the $78 charcuterie board quite as much as I used to, but it's a lovely place for an evening with friends.
author: Claire S.

description:
The duck thing in the Small Charcuterie & Alumni Board was great. The Confit rabbit in the Brown Rice Porridge was juicy and great. The Croque Madame was ok but the pastrami was very hard to eat - it could be cut to slides or less salty and more juicy. Orange juice is ok but feel a slightly bit like concentrate. 

Service was good. The ACME bread was good although personally I like soft bread. They have wifi. 

Love the fact that they have Oolong tea even though I didn't have the chance to try it yet. 

The chair on patio was kind of uncomfortable. 

Love the fact all price include service. 

The napkin was dropping cotton on my sweater all over the place :(
author: Anya C.

description:
Trou Normand makes me wish I had a corporate expense account. For one, I would have enjoyed our overpriced $170 dinner for two more knowing that I did not have to pay for it.

Ok, who am I kidding?  I would need that corporate expense account to woo clients with fancy booze!

As sister restaurant to Bar Agricole with a fantastic bar program making them a James Beard nominee, it was no surprise that I adored their buzzingly strong cocktails at Trou Normand. I had the Demsey: gin, calvados, grenadine, absinthe ($12: http://bit.ly/1nMV5kY) and the Plaza: gin, italian vermouth, pineapple ($12: http://bit.ly/1u3e51A). There wasn't much of it but do they pack a big punch. 

Along with your buzztastic cocktails, their charcuterie menu is not to be missed. Not only are their charcuterie made in-house but there are over 20 selections a day; the most I've ever seen for a restaurant. It doesn't come cheap though. Make your own combo with selections that range from $6-$12 each or choose a chef's platter for $21 - $63. We decided to make our own with dry cured belly, lardo sumac, chicken pate, dry guanciale & headcheese ($42): http://bit.ly/ZY8njl. Everything was top-notch but the dry cured belly and dry guanciale were my favs. Skip the chicken pate, it wasn't rich nor creamy; more like a chicken meatloaf. I wish they threw in some pickled veggies and cornichons to help cut through the salty richness. 

Unfortunately, the praise stops here. 

Their entrees are ridiculously overpriced for mediocrity. Over $30 for an entree with no sides? Their menu changes regularly but you can skip their Roast Pork ($32): http://bit.ly/1rHO3JD if it's on the menu. I was hoping for a crackly skin but it was just incredibly sinewy and flabby. The Pappardelle w/ braised pork shank ($17) fared better but wasn't spectacular: http://bit.ly/1oVr7MD. I wish the noodles had more of a bite to it but it was a bargain compared to the other menu items.  We also ordered the Arancini ($7) which were like bland balls: http://bit.ly/1xAhrpC. 

For dessert, we ordered a slice of Mission Pie's Banana Cream Pie but it was an obviously old slice of pie ($8): http://bit.ly/1yGwwax. Our waiter took it off the bill but my picture of it was flagged and removed (by management?) on Yelp several days later for "misrepresenting the restaurant". Umm who served the old pie? Not moi. Shady. *Tsk Tsk*

Equally unimpressive was the hipster 'tude service. The staff was absolutely wonderful at Bar Agricole; they were welcoming, attentive and swift. Did HR fall asleep at the interview table?

With the exception of the busboys, the hostess and wait staff weren't at the least bit friendly and service was slow as molasses. We had to ask the busboy several times to chase down our waiter because he was MIA or too busy chatting with other servers at the corner. What annoys me is Trou Normand (along with Bar Agricole) will now be charging an 20% auto-gratuity on ALL bills: http://bit.ly/1zesKYV. We always tip a minimum of 18% but a tip should be earned NOT demanded. Besides, you guys aren't the French Laundry or a Saison nor is the service even close to that caliber.

Don't get me started on the communal seating (no individual tables). The fact that you make reservations for date night and then have to share a table with complete strangers? Sorry sir, I'm sure you're a great guy but I give zero phucks about your toe fungus.
author: Cherylynn N.

description:
I'd been waiting for a nice day to try this place, as I really wanted to try the outdoor seating. We had brunch there and it did not disappoint. The garden is beautiful, and though each table was occupied, they were big stone tables, spaced well apart so it remained very tranquil and excellent for conversation. 

I'm always worried when a restaurant is really hyped that the food won't meet my expectation, but this was certainly not the case. The pork sausage sandwich I had came with a spread that was absolutely delicious. The potatoes were also some of the best I have ever had, and I have eaten many many brunch potatoes in my time. The rest of our party had the beef hash and poached eggs, both great choices, but I have to say the sausage sandwich was my favorite. 

I would definitely come here again. The outdoor area has a glass ceiling and heat lamps. They can also lower transparent plastic coverings for the sides, so it's suitable for all weather. I felt that it was on the pricier side, even for a San Francisco brunch, but the ambience really added to the value.
author: Harris L.

description:
Came to this place for brunch . I feel overall exp was 3.5 stars but Yelp does not give that option so 3 . 
Why 3 not 4 , waiter was not attentive enough , after taking the order , he forgot n came back after 10 mins to revise it . Secondary portions were too small for the price , the place shd be $$$ or $$$$ . And third the menu shown online /Yelp does not match the menu they give you there which was the biggest disappointment for me 
On other hand everything we ordered tasted . Cheese toast n fried chicken as starter , scrambled egg , chicken sausage n French toast for mains . All were really good , well balanced with flavours , tasted fresh with wonderful greens n perfect dressing , so  for that .
author: Anshul G.

description:
Great spot to nosh on charcuterie and have some drinks with friends. Love that they have outdoor seating with heat lamps (very necessary for SF). It was too humid inside the actual restaurant for my liking.  Not entirely sure I would do a full blown meal here as the rest of the menu didn't blow me away.

I was a bit sad that the headcheese was not available the night I was there. BOO!!! Our server even told us 4 other tables had inquired. I will have to return another time to catch it. 

Really loved the grilled lardo toast. Although it is essentially fat on a bread, it was executed exceptionally well. Just the right amount of acid, sweetness, fat and crunch. Perfection.
Arancini are definitely worth ordering. Pretty much a deep fried ball of risotto. If you like cheesy and fried things, well yea get it. No brainer.

I didn't care much for the roasted shisito peppers we had. 

We also shared a small charcuterie & salumi board, 4 items, chef's choice. I highly recommend splitting a combo board so you can get a taste of everything. Great charcuterie!
author: Susy C.

description:
Had dinner and drinks here recently with an old coworker and friend. We sat at the bar since they weren't taking walk-ins for tables at the time. I recommend making a reservation ahead.

The bar experience was great as we got to see the magic of some of their signature cocktails. The drinks were tasty and worth a try. 

The meat and cheese boards were plentiful and diverse, albeit a bit pricey, but we didn't have much to complain about. It was all delicious. If you're not too hungry, I recommend grabbing drinks and sharing some small plates and a few boards.
author: Phil C.

description:
The concept of this restaurant is awesome. Slow food, socializing,  and a break from you're meal with a good brandy. The pork chop is out of this world. The tagliatelle is a must, Brussels sprouts are super tasty, and charcuterie plate is house cured meats and payed with fresh acme bread.  Service with a smile is nonexistent,  but great service sans smiles.

Other noteworthy dishes include the black cod, sausages, arancini, and roasted squash.
author: Judy L.

description: The most remarkable thing about Trou Normand is that it is still in business. My recent dinner there was the singular worst meal I have had in SF in many years. If our waitress had only been ignorant and negligent, that would have been a positive. She was rude and disrespectful to boot. The food was overpriced, poorly made, and over salted to an extreme. Don't waste your money-- just go next door to Mourad for a spectacular meal.
author: Pascal L.

description:
After an evening of drinking, our group of 5 came to Trou Normand for a late dinner. I've had Trou Normand bookmarked for some time for their cocktails, charcuterie and cheese so I couldn't wait to finally try them out.

Since we'd been drinking all evening, I only tried one cocktail: their old fashioned. But altogether, we ordered:
-House old fashioned: single house cognac, two bitters ($12)
-Hawaiian: calvados, chartreuse, pineapple, lime ($12)
-Russell 6y rye manhattan ($14)

For food we got:
-Cheese board: Dorset, Brescianella stagionata, Lord of the hundreds ($20)
-Large charcuterie & salumi board: 8 selections, chosen by the chef ($42)
-Arancini ($7)
-Pork meatballs: pomodoro ($14)
-Pappardelle: braised pork shank ragu ($17)
-Roasted shishitos & padrons: eggplant, curry, nardellos ($10)

I really liked the Cheese board and Charcuterie board. So much, that I basically ate only those two things. The rest, I had a bite each, but those two were my favorites. 

I'll probably come back so I can try more of their cocktails and of course get those delicious cheese and charcuterie boards!
author: Elena N.

description:
Came here for lunch on a Monday with my boss. We got seated right away which is awesome. The booths are fairly long for two people but it was fine. They also have an outdoor patio seating for nicer days. We ordered from their lunch menu:

- 4 choices charcuterie: all selections were delicious with the acme bread. They will provide more bread if you'd like without additional cost.
- squash salad: different squashes cut into thin slices in a salad, very delicious and nothing overpowered the original taste of each veggie.
- beef ragu: delicious as well! Noodles were perfect softness and the beef were shredded and tender as well.

Overall, super enjoyed our lunch here. Waiter kept checking on us every so often which was cool. I also had a fresh orange juice which was the perfect sweetness as well. Will definitely want to return :)
author: Amanda C.

description:
I went here for a vendor event and the stuff I tried was pretty amazing. 

Charcuterie meats. 

Pork Loin. Black Cod,  and Brussel Sprouts. 

They have an awesome back eating area that was just a surprise for me and a great place to congregate.  I thoroughly enjoyed this place.   I will definitely need to go back to try out more items on the menu.
author: Homer S.

description:
I don't really have much to say about Trou Normand because I didn't get to try their best stuff when I unfortunately visited during Lent which I gave up Beef and Pork..  However, I must say that this is a very cozy looking bar and their drinks and Charcuterie meats are really good!

Select Charcuterie -- http://bit.ly/1n84f9I
This was a very impressive board of Select Charcuterie meats.  Though can't remember everything that was on the board, simply because most of the stuff I wasn't able to eat because of Lent, I do remember there being some kind of duck pate that was awesome!

Petrale Sole --  http://bit.ly/1jGVdNB
For my main entree I decided on trying the Petrale Sole.  Wouldn't have been my first choice, but it was the only thing on their menu that I was only able to try since I gave up beef and pork.  While the sole was nice and buttery, I was definitely struggling with the bones.  Despite my best efforts to remove the vertebrae and connecting bones, there were still a ton of bones left in the fish.  So basically one out of every three bites had some kind of bone in it that I had to spit out.

Aside from the Sole, I did enjoy the drinks and what I had on the Charcuterie board.  If I'm in the area, I'd definitely stop over for a drink and a small plate of selected meats.  I would definitely come back to visit again to try all their other entrees, especially now that they have a breakfast and lunch menu, and also they just opened their outdoor patio as well.  So hopefully with my next visit, I'll have a more enjoyable time.
author: Rodney H.

description:
I loved Trou Normand even before I learned that the name means something like "take a shot of brandy between each course". Trou is like "gap" in French... so, you're filling that gap between courses with brandy, like they do in Normandy. What's not to love about that?

But really, Trou Normand is more about cocktails & meat plates than they are about brandy shots. Come for some fancy pants drinks in antique coupes & charcuterie to scare the pants off any vegetarian. There's multiple layers to the space: a stark modern bar & dining area, and indoor sunroom-type space in the back, and a big patio they're working on with an outdoor bar. In short, it's the coolest spot in SOMA which manages to feel like a hidden gem in the midst of corporate-y New Montgomery.

For girls night, date night, biz lunch or dinner, morning coffee (yes, they do that too!)...any excuse to hang at Trou Normand is a good one.
author: Nique F.

description:
Trou Normand is an upscale, elegant cocktail bar and restaurant in SoMa. I came here for a company event that had the whole back room reserved with an open bar and a small buffet of dishes (mostly appetizers that are typically served here). Overall, I was extremely impressed by the quality and deliciousness of both the cocktails and the food.

From the bar, I started with a cocktail called the Brown Derby, made from bourbon, grapefruit, lemon, honey, and aromatic bitters. I'll admit that I'm no expert on cocktails, but this drink was very delicious and was the perfect mix of sweet, tart, and slightly bitter. I went on to the buffet of appetizers and was extremely impressed--some of the standouts to me were the duck pate and rabbit pate (which both had extremely distinct flavors characteristic of the two meats), the arancini, which was creamy and smoky with a distinct flavor from the anise, and, my favorite by far, the pork meatballs. "Meatballs" was a bit of a misnomer, as this dish consisted of chunks of ground pork that were grilled, sliced, and served over an absolutely wonderful, savory tomato-based sauce. Towards the end of the evening, there were a plate of cookies put out on the bar as well, and I absolutely loved the peanut butter and the chocolate chip cookies, which were chewy, soft, and buttery!

Overall, Trou Normand was a fantastic venue for our company event--though I didn't have a typical "dinner" here, the flavors of the dishes and drinks I did try were all unique and delicious, and it would be a fun experience to return!
author: David K.

description:
Fancy place.  

After trying to get into Pink Elephant for brunch and there being a ridiculous long line and for whatever reason, my friend didn't want to do bottomless, so we ended up at Trou Normand. Drinkswise, since everyone was hungover still (except me), we didn't end up getting drinks.  I ended up ordering the poached eggs with corned beef hash and we shared a plate of the pork belly.  The pork belly was nicely fried and oh so tender. 

However, I had to come back another night to try their charcuterie board. I came in on a Friday night and there weren't too many people. They had a few seats at the bar so I sat down and ordered a drink and the small board. The drink I got was the Hawaiian.  It was good but by the end of it, I felt like I was drinking the alcohol and not the mixers. 

The charcuterie board was great with the 4 choices - the dried cured belly, rabbit pate, salami, and mortadella. I think my favorites were the salami and the pate. 

Pro tip: charcuterie board with friends.
author: Nina Y.

description:
We got a reservation for a special celebration, and got seated outside on the lovely patio. To get to the patio, you have to walk through where they hang out all the pig parts and cut and cure them, so if you're a meat lover, you should definitely go take a look.

Apart from some delicious complimentary bubblies, we got a couple cocktails to start, and they were really good and well-balanced. Then we shared the charcuterie board, the pork burger, and the tagliatelle. As promised (by the meat display!), all the meats were delicious, and we hoped we had more of it, especially on the charcuterie board.

They closed the dining area at 2:30pm after lunch time for an event, but we were still eating. They are very nice to help us move indoors to another spot so we can continue with desserts.

Definitely come here when you crave some meat.
author: Alice C.

description:
We had brunch here on a Saturday during a break from visiting the SF MOMA.  It's very close to the museum.  We were able to sit in the glass enclosed outdoor patio area, which was kind of cool.  We had Open Table reservations, but it looked like there were some available tables.

The service was a slow to get started.  We ordered the Red Flannel Hash and the Poached Eggs.  Everything was good.  The beer menu was not bad, I had a Tap It IPA.  We would come back if we were in the area again.
author: Dan L.

description: We thought the food was excellent and the service was spot on. Would highly recommend if you are visiting San Francisco.
author: Melissa T.

description:
Humans seek comfort in many ways.

We all have our rituals: going for a run, getting a massage, meditating. 

Some prefer to engage in rituals of social drinking ... yes, moi. 

Even though I wasn't able to engage in my usual rituals because of lent, I am proud to say that I was able to survive it sans alcohol. It has been a long and arduous journey, my friends.

You should see how many times bartenders would stop and think whenever I request for a mocktail. Or the numerous times when I just had an "OK" mocktail and I shake my head because I'm wasting calories on something that doesn't even taste good.

Trou Normand blew me away. Coming from the Bar Agricole team, I knew they'd have top notch bartenders. But she made me a mocktail with pineapple, ginger, lime and a touch of cream at the top. I like the foamy presentation! And the best part? it actually TASTED so, so good. For a MOCKTAIL.  Can you imagine what she could do with the real thing?!  I'm in LOVE already.

I'm also in love with the beautiful space. It's very New York: high concrete ceilings, exposed brick, roomy leather tufted booths. Modern art on the walls. Sexy, minimalist space suited for the after work crowd in the Fidi. 

The charcuterie selection is very impressive. With over 20 housemade concoctions, I had a difficult time narrowing my choices to just 6. The duck galantine with pear, rosemary and cinnamon was the standout of the crew. Others we tried were mortadella, lardo, porcini/anise salami and duck pate. Ask for plenty of pain epi acme bread to go with it. 

The entrees were all equally good and well prepared. Lamb ragu, the lamb 3 ways, Petrale sole and roasted pork coppa.  However, the price point (it didn't include sides) is very expensive. Separate charges for sides? come on, this isn't a steakhouse.

Depending on the mood, the "European style" service might not be for some and towards the end we had to flag her down for our check. The good thing is, they will not kick you out of here no matter how long you want to stay at the table. In fact, we stayed way past closing time.

I'd visit again to luxuriate over well made cocktails paired with meaty goodness from their charcuterie selection. Thank God lent is over, this is a place my liver is worth sacrificing for.
author: Janice C.

description:
Teeny-tiny spot, ain't it? But with high ceilings, of course (it's SoMa after all), and its setting in the Pac Bell building gives it an appropriate retro-vintage vibe that makes it a magnet for hipster foodies (photo: http://bit.ly/1nVJQW9). It's no surprise that Yelp has moved into the classic Art Deco building, and this makes an ideal happy hour destination if you can manage to grab a seat at the bar. You can eat here, and a lot of the small plates looked delicious as they whizzed by, but be forewarned there are only five booths and a community table in the back. Jamie W. and I came for the cocktails, and we weren't disappointed.

Before we ordered, we couldn't help but notice the large sketch of a naked woman in repose on the wall. Despite the scale, the approach to the drawing is quite minimal, somehow suitable for the casual ambiance (photo: http://bit.ly/1lyU0WK). Similar to Bar Agricole, Trou Normand offers a seductive mixed drink selection, and the bartender helped us sift through the choices. Jamie settled on the $11 Hawaiian, a tantalizing tropical mix of Calvados, chartreuse, pineapple and lime, that had nothing to do with a Blue Hawaii. I went for the slightly more urban $11 Brandy Scaffa, which blended raspberry and chartreuse into the cognac (photo: http://bit.ly/1jI4bGE). The combination packed a subtle wallop that lured me into ordering another.

Although the $27 Grilled Pork Chop and the $38 Charcuterie Plate looked worthy enough for a satisfying meal, we had just eaten at Henry's Hunan across the street so we were in no condition to gorge. But something sweet was not out of the question, and they offer a couple of desserts. We decided to share a $9 slice of the Apple Rhubarb Mission Pie a la Mode (photo: http://bit.ly/1t4tpGL). Sure, it was tasty but hardly reflective of their kitchen, I hope. Anyway, timing is everything if you plan on coming after work or on the weekends. We got lucky since we got the last two available seats at the bar, but others were hovering quite a bit before giving up entirely. They should just relax and have a couple of Trou Normand shots to neutralize their Type-A personalities.

FOOD/DRINKS - 4 stars...I can't go by the pie alone, but the cocktails are easily on par with the ones served at Bar Agricole
AMBIANCE - 4 stars...small as it is, I like the casual vibe in here
SERVICE - 4.5 stars...the bartenders are stellar here
TOTAL - 4 stars...would definitely like to come back for a little pig, a little salumi and a whole lotta cocktails
author: Ed U.

description: What an incredible experience! Everything from the impeccable service to the amazing cocktails (get the Jersey City you won't regret it) to the amazing food and atmosphere. The charcuterie to start was delicious (the paté was my personal favorite), the Pork Chop really is all it's hyped up to be, and the Denver cut steak was cooked to perfection. This place is without a doubt a San Fransisco staple!
author: Sarah L.

description:
Lets talk BRUNCH.

I initially wanted to go to Pink Elephant, but 2 hour wait?? Not down, so I came here as an alternative and was impressed!!

So first of all, the high ceilings, abundance of natural lighting, and overall layout immediately appealed to me. It felt like a hybrid between an art gallery + green house + simplified Anthropologie-esque restaurant. 

Now the food. A bit on the pricey side, about ~$20 a person for just the food. 
I ordered the french toast and it was Beautiful!! Lots of fresh strawberries, this berry syrup, and honeybutter to top it off! It was delicious.
My boyfriend ordered the Pork Belly and that was delicious as well. Colorful beans, a lightly cooked egg and thick slices of pork belly. 

I would definitely not recommend coming here if you're starving because the portions are not particularly large...but if you're looking for a nice brunch place where you can sit down, eat slowly and chat with someone..this is the place for you!! Its really a wonderful and early environment where you can sit back and enjoy a beautiful meal .
author: Katie 2.

description: bad food, very salty, limited menu, limited wine selection and wine was served hot. service was over eager and annoying. and as usual over priced. the best part: when the kitchen closed the music stope as well and lights were turned back on to rush us to leave,,not recommended and we are not going back.
author: Myrto K.

description: Great pork belly entree and excellent service. Would definitely recommend for a nice dinner out, great for romantic date or medium-sized groups!
author: Leeni L.

description:
This is how you celebrate:

* You win your court case by smoking the defendant.
* Drink a smoke induced mescal laced cocktail to start.
* Order the smoked duck.
* Cuddle up with your smoking hot lady.
* Finish with a nice smoke from a Montecristo #2.

Oh well...at least some of those were true that night.  Just trust me that the 40 minute wait for the smoked duck was well worth it.  In the words of our past cigar smoking Governor, I'll be back.
author: Ron L.

description:
One of my girlfriends and I dropped by on a random Thursday night.... Without a reservation. That's right, we're big risk takers. 

We were greeted promptly at the door by a cheerful host who informed us that the wait would be 30 minutes. My buddy was less than pleased--but I don't think she was within her right on this one. If I go to a restaurant such as TN without a reservation, I don't expect that I'll be seated promptly. It's all about managing your expectations, after all. At any rate, I'm okay with that, however, as I use the extra time as an excuse to imbibe a few extra adult beverages. 

My friend and I both ordered champagne. I note that TN has an impressive cocktail menu, although you'll also note that my days of "craft cocktails" are pretty much over. I don't like waking up with fried rice in my hair. At all. 

We were sat at a community table, much to my friend's chagrin. Having spent many years in the People's Republic of Berkeley, I am less abject to community seating, although I admit that I don't love it. It wasn't that bad at TN, but please be advised you're going to see a big hipster factor. You should prepare accordingly. 

Onto food. We ordered a side of broccoli, a side of peas, and a side of polenta. All three of these dishes sound pretty boring, don't they? Not a chance. All three were slammin. Whatever sauce those peas were in? Yes, please. Pretty expensive for a side of veggies - noted for the record. 

We ordered apple rhubarb pie with ice cream for dessert. I've never had anything rhubarb before, and this was a pleasing introduction. It was decent, and definitely satisfied my seemingly unsatisfiable sweet tooth. 

Overall, TN was a pretty good experience. Brace yourself for hipsters. Enjoy a few drinks at the bar. Prepare to lay down some dinero. You'll be fine.
author: Sunny S.

description:
This place is incredible. My first time eating there was this week and everything was on point...

FOOD - 4 star - we ordered the duck confit dumpling and the pork burger. Both were delicious. The burger was just a bit rich for my tastes, but still great. The charcuterie board was also fantastic. 

DRINKS - 5 star - the wine list and house specialty cocktails were unbelievably good. If it hadn't been in the middle of a workday...

AMBIENCE- 5 star - the room is great. Intimate, hip, clean. 

SERVICE - 5 star - the service might have been the best part. Our waitress was amazing.
author: Brandon W.

description: I think this place is great. The pork chop...you know you want it.  Charcuterie that is fresh and tastes homemade.  Served atop hand hewn brown beautiful wood boards.  Great service. Nice unpretentious atmosphere.  Wonderful craft cocktails.  But definitely not two dollar signs.  More like three.
author: Darby W.

description:
I have the say that this will be a gem well talked about in future conversations about libations and adventures in edible delights. This place reminds me of a New York City apartment with a San Francisco chill vibe. Make sure to get friendly with the mixologists and they won't steer you wrong. 

Trou Normand is truly magnificent. Grab your cocktails and reminisce about past and future travels as you're transported into another level of elegance with leather tufted booths and concrete countertops. Enjoy and tell your friends. Or don't for that matter - we want to save the best for ourselves.
author: Kevin J.

description: Horrible food and service in a beautiful space.  Overpriced and flavorless brunch....   never offered drinks and we waited way too long for food considering the restaurant was empty and we both ordered eggs.  Mine with toast which came out almost burnt and cold, and served with cold unsalted butter.  Yuck.  My husbands potatoes that 8.00 and about 1 cup total were the only thing worth eating.  Plus it took forever for our oblivious server to get our bill.   Hard pass
author: K G.

description:
The sides were almost the same price as the entrees.  Even Nopa doesn't charge their avocado toast $15.  Is this place even Michelin rated?  Why am I paying this much for mediocre food?  Why did I agree to go here?  

So many questions.
author: Jacquelynne S.

description: The cocktails here are great. The food is good, but is SO overpriced. I can't justify paying $24 for 2 meatballs. And that's all you get for $24. Definitely stop in for a cocktail or two, but go elsewhere for a meal. And the patio area is not the best. The patio is covered by a tent that bounces sound everywhere. Not the best place to have a conversation.
author: Vanessa S.

description:
OMG. Tagilatelle. Get the tagilatelle! 

I headed over to Trou Normand with some coworkers after a long day at a conference and we were not disappointed. We started with a medium charcuterie board which had many more options than I expected. I love a good prosciutto and salami, but the bread was the real star of here. Perfectly crusty and soft all at the same time--yum! 

Our group opted to order a few dishes and share. The salads were good, but they were salads. The real starts of the meal were the entrees. The roasted chicken was fantastic. Perfectly moist with a ton of flavor. But the pasta, oh the pasta! As someone who grew up around a lot of Italian in Chicago, I like to think I've got high standards when it comes to pasta, and this Tagilatelle did not disappoint. The noodles were fresh and soft and topped with the most flavorful pomodoro sauce. It was SO GOOD we ordered another. 

The only thing holding me back from running back for another meal was the price. Our bill (drinks and dessert) was over $450 for five people. The entrees alone were $25-45 and they came as pure entrees, no vegetable or starch sides included. The food was delicious, but this is certainly not an everyday place.
author: Sydney L.

description: I would give this place another star if it weren't so freaking expensive. 4 delicious risotto rice arancini balls came out piping hot for $8, but they were absolutely tiny and only had a fingernail's worth of meat inside. The best deal was definitely the small chef's selection of charcuterie and salumi for $26. We ended up with some delicious cuts of meat and pretty solid epi baguettes, and we couldn't complain about the mojo deconstructed pork hash either, but prices are really, really high. While the ingredients are top notch, and service is expedient, food comes out really slowly, and they forgot a couple of our orders. Their patio was a nice way to spend an hour on a sunny SF afternoon, but once was enough for the price point. Love the interior space as well. The curved booths and bar and speakeasy feel made for some great ambiance.
author: Danny C.

description:
Their food is good. I enjoyed most of it besides the "schnitzel". Born and raised in Germany, I wouldn't call that a "Schnitzel. It was dry, barely meat and very greasy sides veggies, I'd rather have the fat&flavor in my schnitzel than the veggies. 

They also did not offer sweetener for their brunch coffee or gluten free bread.
I have actual gluten intolerance, so it was a bummer I couldn't enjoy the Charcuterie plate fully. :)
author: Li S.

description:
I came here for my friend's birthday last evening. I was SUPER excited to come here -- it's been on my list for a while considering that their drinks are supposed to be top notch.

We got there at 8:30 pm -- we had reservations. We had to wait a tiny bit, but it wasn't too long before we got seated.

Between the 6 of us, we ordered the following:
1) MEDIUM CHARCUTERIE + SALUMI BOARD: 8 items. I can't recall what we had exactly, but I have to say -- everything on there was just top notch. My favorite was the chicken pâteé.
2) BUTTER LETTUCE: Very good -- the chèvre complimented the strawberries excellently.
3) SUMMER SQUASH: I love squash. I love pesto. However, the dish was slightly underwhelming. Would skip.
4) ARANCINI: This was so good that we ordered TWO of them (it was also because we had 6 people and it only comes in 4). But damn, it was hella good. I was trying to consume it as fast as I can despite the fact that it was burning hot from the kitchen. haha
5) PICKLES: Pickled varieties. Great little starter.

6) GRILLED PORK CHOP: MAN. This was hella good. I loved it. Would definitely recommend!
7) TAGLIATELLE: We were all definitely amazed by this dish. We were all super impressed and very happy with the pasta.
8) HALIBUT: I didn't have much of this, but wasn't amazed by this dish like how I was with the rest of the entrées that we orderd.
9) PORK MEATBALLS: Maybe I'm a sucker for meat in red sauce. This was REALLY good as well.

10) GRILLED CORN: Didn't have much of this -- just had the corn and no padrons. I think I could've passed.
11) JAPANESE EGGPLANT: Surprisingly not bad. The lamb panchetta with the eggplant and the yogurt complimented each other well. I was a little worried at first, but dannnng - it was good. 

AND THEN WE ORDERED DESSERT:
12) SEMOLINA CAKE: The strawberry sauce was just SO GOOD. This is a great cake for those who like something light.
13) MEYER LEMON TART: I'm usually a big fan of lemon tarts, but I think because the other two desserts that I had were SUPER sweet that this tasted WAY too sour. Wish I had this before all the other desserts.
14) CHOCOLATE POT DE CREME: I'm usually not a big fan of chocolate-related desserts. However, this was AMAZING. The toffee crunch was just the cherry on top.

DRINKS: We all ordered something different. I, myself, had the Brown Derby. Definite recommend to those who like something a little sour. I would've ordered more if I wasn't a small Asian girl with poor alcohol tolerance.

Our waitress Rachel was a sweetie as well. Management came by every and now and then to make sure we were having a great dinner. They also came by to give us some of their house special wine from Normandy. Their Trou Normand. It supposedly had some apple and peaches hint to it, but it was quite strong with alcohol content.

Overall, great food. Great service. Great company.
author: Joanne W.

description:
Came here for lunch. A little pricey, but my friend and I deserved it after having some stressful days at work. 

Started off with the SMALL CHARCUTERIE & SALUMI BOARD. 4 types the chef chooses for you. Comes with acme bread and you can ask for more if it's not enough. I liked the difference selections and they didn't all taste the same.

ARANCINI Genoa salame-so good. This is a must. 

We wanted to try the burger, but went for the salad instead. Glad we did because even though the portions aren't that big, it was very filling. CHOPPED SALAD w/ salame, egg, yellow wax beans, tomatoes, corn, and pecorino. Refreshing! Perfect with this meal.

I'll be back to treat myself again on a stressful day. 

They don't really have any small tables. It's a really small restaurant so if they do get busy at lunch I think you would have to share a table. Service was nice.
author: Karen H.

description: The food here is AMAZING so I absolutely hate that I can't give them 5 stars. And if it were for how amazing the food is, I'd give them only 1 star because the service was so bad, especially considering the price point.  They ignored us, never checked on us. We'd have to flag them them to get their attention to order. They also just missed basics like making sure you have your drinks before they start bringing your appetizers to the table. And the service was far from friendly. The host seemed agitated when we arrived 10 mins early and our server seemed really stressed out. She probably had too many tables but she still didn't need to snap at my friend when she was trying go get her attention. Come on Trou Normand staff, your outstanding menu deserves to be paired with better service!
author: F S.

description: I chose this place based on previous reviews and also on its proximity to MOMA (we were going there afterwards). Their brunch menu is extremely minimal -- even smaller in person than what it shows online -- especially if you aren't into salami or unusual cheeses. My husband ordered the burger and it was supposed to be cooked medium rare. The burger was completely raw. It honestly looked like it had been formed and put directly on the bun, never touched a grill. He ended up having to send it back, so we had to wait for one to be cooked properly. The burger did not come with any sort of side and they did not deduct it from our bill or give us a discount, even after the inconvenience. I eat a lot of vegetarian dishes, and pretty much the only options in that regard were the salad and the French toast. The French toast was good, but it was not worth the price. Our friend had a strawberry soda, my husband had one cocktail, I drank water, we ordered a couple small snacks (almonds and olives) and each of us had an entree. Our bill was $96. Not worth it. We won't come back here next time we are in San Francisco.
author: Jess J.

description:
5 stars for the food, service, patio, and included tip. 1 star for the coffee..

Two weekends in a row and we will definitely go back. A great brunch option for soma that you can actually get into. 

Dishes are always different, with top notch meat butchered on location. Amazing bacon. Yum!!
author: Katelyn W.

description:
I used to dream about Trou Normand's breakfast sandwiches (and the biscuit! with homemade jam!), and then they stopped serving breakfast.

And then, what was already a pricey drink treat got more expensive-- a menu photo from 2014 shows mixed drinks at $10-11, wines around $10-13, and beer around $6-9. Currently, mixed drinks are $15, wines are mostly $15, and beers start at $9 for a Stiegl (which sells for less than $3 in a store). Last year it was already steep given the mixed drinks are in smaller-than-average glasses, but $15 is just too much; even at Valencia street's or the Embarcadero's fanciest restaurants (or Mourad, in the same building!), the cocktails are $11-13.

I love the house-made charcuterie and staff revenue-sharing concept, the latter of which I understand usually raises the price of an average item. But it was already expensive before, and they've always included service. This latest increase just felt excessive without any discernible value-add.

As for the space itself: the design is lovely-looking, but there's hardly enough room between the bar and the tables. When I was seated recently, the host interrupted a group who'd been sitting on the edge of what became my table, but she didn't wipe it down. Those people continued to hover next to the table because there wasn't anywhere else for them to go. Not good for groups if you're just getting drinks without a reservation (we made one for precisely this reason). Additionally, because of their limited tables and permanent booths, smaller parties are often seated at the same table as other parties. 

There's nothing terribly wrong with the food, service, or drinks, all of which are enjoyable. It's mostly that the price/quantity/value ratio doesn't compete, and I probably wouldn't go out of my way to visit again.
author: Krista L.

description:
Excellent meal due largely to the recommendations and service received from Chris behind the bar.  He guided us thru the menu making the best recommendations and pairings.

Recommended: Pork duo with pork loin and pork belly, carrot and blood orange salad and don't forget to start with the charcuterie 

The meal was the best I've had in San Fran
author: Jeff B.

description:
Team lunch summary:

+
Patio
Nice waiter 

- 
We literally got 3 mini slices of a potato with our burgers, and 1 small leaf of lettuce. I don't even know how this got out of the kitchen considering how poor it looked.
Burger too greasy.
The espresso was definitely not good and way too long.
Definitely overpriced for the quality and quantity.

Plenty of better places in the city!
author: Carole P.

description: The food was pretty good but the portions were on the smaller end. The main reason why I am giving Trou Normand three stars is because of service. The restaurant was not too busy (I came here on a Saturday night at around 7:30 PM), and our waiter was not very attentive. It was hard to flag anybody down to take our order because we were in a communal room. At a restaurant of this caliber, I was expecting more attentive service and not have to wait 20 minutes for our waiter to come back and get our order at a not-so-busy hour. This place is a good place for a date night. Expect to pay at least $30+ a person for dinner after tax and tip. I would only come back here if it's the only place that does not have a wait in the area or happen to be not very hungry.
author: Lynn T.

description:
Can't say enough great things about this place. Let's start with :

1. Tip is included in prices. Hello Europe. Love that. 

2. Super friendly staff. Let me have my pup on the patio, which I might add is a very fine patio.

3. Super low key as this place is a hidden gem. 

4. Food is killer.

5. They offer pay by phone via Open Table which is great if you like to get in, stuff your face, then get out.
author: Ashlyn R.

description:
I'm at that point in my life where I prefer to spend my birthday as more of an introvert than my usual extrovert style.  After having a fairly quiet day to myself, it was nice to gather a handful of my friends together for something I had been waiting a long time for: Trou Normand's charcuterie and salumi board.  Being the classy people that we are, we ordered the Large board and the cheese plate almost right away as we sipped on various wines and bubbly. Everyone, including our token Frenchie who we consider an expert in wine, cheese and cured meats, was impressed with the delicious pâté options and absolutely amazing charcuterie.  A few favorites were the rabbit pâté, the chicken pâté, and the pancetta.  The cheese plate didn't get as many rave reviews, and most of us considered the cheese plate to be mediocre relative to the charcuterie and pâté spread.  Things were winding down on the meat and cheeses when our true selves were revealed: we were still hungry.  So, in perfect form, we went with two orders of the Aracini after we perused on Yelp what else we should get, and also two orders of the pork meatballs after being recommended by our server.  I'm so glad we did, being proper and wanting to just eat meat and cheese for dinner is, well, overrated.  Those fried balls of risotto hit the spot, and the meatball, while lacking in presentation, made up in taste. For dessert, we all shared the chocolate pot du creme, and because it was my special day, we were also given the Meyer Lemon tart.  Both were delicious, but neither were outstanding.

I absolutely loved celebrating my birthday at Trou, and I would strongly recommend that you come here when you have a large group.  I concluded that if my husband and I were to come here by ourselves, we'd be leaving either hungry, unsatisfied, or both.  So, if you need a great place for a small and intimate group of friends, I definitely recommend Trou Normand!
author: Lisa I.

description:
I came to Trou Normand for a work lunch and I'm glad that was the case. I think my review would sing a different tune if I had to pay for my meal at my own expense.

With that said, the food is good, but not exceptional. I loved the beautiful minimalistic decor and the outdoor heated patio seating is my favorite part about dining at Trou Normand. It almost made me feel like I was no longer in FiDi of SF!

What I tried:

CHARCUTERIE BOARD - As everyone else mentioned, the charcuterie board is a must try here. Although I can't quite tell you exactly what was on our board, I can say that it was delicious. I highly recommend checking out their impressive charcuterie board that's made in-house.

PATTY MELT - Can't really go wrong with this! It was a little on the saltier side for my taste, but it was by no means, a bad patty melt. 

Will I be back to Trou Normand? Maybe. I personally think the food and drinks are slightly over priced, but I'm still open to coming back again.
author: Tiffany U.

description:
Came here with a group of 9 people on Saturday evening. It was completely dead (which in retrospect I shouldn't have been surprised by given the location). We were seated at an enormous booth which seemed really cool but then we realized that you couldn't hear anyone except those on either side of you. 

I am retrospectively writing this review and I actually already cant remember what ordered other than that it was overpriced and underwhelming. I think this is probably a great place for an after work cocktail with a side of charcuterie but since I dont work downtown, I probably wont be back.
author: Molly S.

description: Very disappointing service and food is meh. Tough slow cooked pork. Very boring grilled squash. Took an extremely long time to get a second round of drinks. Cocktails were also just ok.
author: S R.

description: Came here for dinner and we ordered the NY steak and the Pork chops per our waiter's recommendation - was told that both are the best steak and pork chops in town! Well.... they were not! The steak came out as a slab of meat with no sides or sauce. The pork chop also came out as a slab of meat. They do not have any sauces on the side for the meat! The meat needed seasoning. So if you're a member of the Flitstones go for it - Otherwise there are plenty of better options in the city for quality food.
author: Sparkle S.

description: This place is a little slice of heaven. If I could give it more then 5 stars I would. The food is so good that my vegetarian girlfriend salivates over the meat dishes. No expense was spared making every last detail just perfect. The seating, art, bathroom, staff and of course the FOOD all add up to make this my hands down favorite date spot.
author: Adam F.

description:
Great new spot in SF opened by the same people behind Bar Agricole. If you come, try sitting in the front room where it is more atmospheric. Even better, take seats at the Bar and chat with one of the founders of the restaurant, Eric, who is super friendly and knowledgeable.

Trou Normand is known for their meats, and they butcher everything themselves. The charcuterie plate has many options beyond the typical cold meats offered by other restaurants and wine bars. Try Lambrusco (sparking red from Italy) which suppose to be one of the best wines for Charcuterie.

The sausage plate was solid but not exceptional. very flavorful. 
Roasted Allium (roasted spring onion, fennel, etc) was an interesting side dish that complements the meats quite well.

Eric was so generous that he offered us a taste of Trou Normand (a digestive before desserts). Potent. Definitely different from the wimpy cocktails that I usually gravitate to.

Affogato was also quite good for dessert.
The Teutonic Pinot Noir from Willemette Valley was great.

Lovely evening!
author: Rebecca C.

description:
I really wanted to love this place but had a pretty bad experience and left feeing very disappointed. 

What went wrong?
1. There's no doubt about it. It's expensive.  I don't care about that, if it's good - then charge whatever you want. Mostly it wasn't good though and the portions are tiny so it's worth mentioning upfront that this place is $$$$$$. 

2. No one knew anything about the wine list. I asked about a $65 bottle of Chardonnay from the Jura. The server said he'd never tried it but heard it was good. I asked for more definitive information.  He came back and said that he'd asked two other staff and they said they also "liked it".  I find it hard to believe there were no other notes from the sommelier (or the wine rep!) that they could have shared. Or even made something up! This seemed slack and what I'd expect in a basic chain restaurant. 

2. We split a mixed charcuterie plate to start. It was delicious. Condiments weren't right for the dish though. It felt incomplete. The meats themselves seemed good. It was really pricey for tiny thin slices of cured meat. We had to ask bread which seemed stupid. 

3. Our main course - the pork chop special and a side of asparagus - came before we had finished our appetizer. I asked if the chef was in a rush and the server asked if I wanted him to take the food back to the kitchen. I said no, but it seemed a bit amateur that it was sent out in the first place. 

4. The asparagus was tiny. And $18 (I think?). The point is it was very small and very expensive. It was also too heavily seasoned meaning way too salty. 

5. The pork chop was under cooked. I don't care if the chef disagrees pork should be mostly opaque the whole way through and slightly pink in the middle. It was translucent and could only be described as rare. We only ate half of it. We let the server know and he took it off the bill which was not expected but a nice gesture. 

So in a matter of about 45 minutes we had dessert menus on the table and we were ready to leave! The server offered us a complementary glass of calvados, the essence of trou normand. Too little too late! 

Avoid this place for now. They have a lot to figure out. It has so much potential though! I hope they improve!!
author: Luke S.

description:
A trendy restaurant with personality!! The Charcuterie boards are impeccable. All the meats are done at location, done in a variety of styles and seasonings, and may I say that they are delicious. All the cheeses are locally done. The staff is very knowledgeable of what is on the menu so dont be afraid to ask for recommendations or explanations of what things are. 

Take advantage of the wonderful patio they have outside with the speakeasy inspired cocktail menu that is sure to leave you with a smile. I would also recommend ordering some entrees and sharing them tapas style. The calamari is spicy good and the pork chop is divine beyond words.
author: Raul V.

description:
Trou Normand is a charcuterie, French style restaurant with seating both inside and out. Reservations are recommended (open table) but not required. My husband and I dined here for brunch the day before the SF Marathon and were surprised by how many open spots there were. Meter spots in the area still run on Saturdays (not on Sundays) so we parked near Yerba Buena Gardens and walked over. Inside seating offers bar or tables and they do have bar hooks for the ladies :) the brunch menu is ever changing so keep that in mind if you book your reservation more than a week out. We started with a goat cheese and pepper jelly on toast for an appetizer and it did not disappoint. My husband ordered the braised pork with lipstick peppers (not spicy) and a fried egg and was completely blown away by the depth of flavors. I ordered the scrambled eggs with beans and edamame and cheese and it was light and delicious and the eggs were the best scrambled eggs I have ever had. It's not an hyperbole but rather truth. The eggs were moist and airy and just delicious. I could have ordered more but the $20+ price tag definitely held me back. If you like meat order their charcuterie, it's what they are famous for, but... If you are a meatless eater like myself, order the eggs :) oh and make sure to Yelp this place afterwards. They are after all, located right next to Yelp.

Atmosphere 5*
Service 5*
Food 5*
Location 5*
Price 4*
author: Kristina Nichole D.

description:
About half the time I go somewhere nice, I'm disappointed. This place was definitely in the other half. I had a fantastic experience!

The drinks are really tasty, made well, non GMO, organic, and lovely. The food is divine, too, even for a vegetarian palate. I got the summer squash, and whatever they do to it (sprinkle a little crack on top? It is addictive), it is the best I can ever recall having. The arancini was equally delicious. I had no idea what I was in for, but the waitress Nikki suggested it, so I ordered it. The arancini is deep fried balls of risotto with a little ball of cheese inside. It is kind of like classy fair food, and ridiculously good. I tried to savor them, but part of me just wanted to shovel them into my mouth.

The price was not bad at all, considering how good everything was, and I'm usually pretty cheap. I'll be back!
author: Christopher L.

description: Bold and beautiful are two words I'd use to describe this restaurant. The menu was diverse enough to suit almost any palette and appetite! I thought our waitress was informative and helpful throughout our entire visit. My only complaint was that our service was on the slow side and our food took a long time to arrive. I will definitely be returning as a happy customer and recommend the halibut toast and fried egg rabbit confit hash to everyone.
author: Heidi J.

description:
The selection of charcuterie in this place is absolutely phenomenal - from goat to lamb to rabbit to duck... There is so much to try and be amazed with!
Great spot for Happy Hours as well as memorable dinners.
Love how the menu always changes, but some amazing staples stay the same, like the mouth watering meatballs.
author: Olga G.

description:
Outstanding Brunch. Came here with some food writers and bloggers who really know their food. We all enjoyed everything that we ate. The space is beautiful and the servers are graceful.

 Some stand out dishes were the Charcuterie plate, which are all made in-house. The fig French toast was also amazing.  To drink order the ginger beer and all of their cocktails l. 

I can't wait to go back and enjoy another brunch on their patio.
author: Teresa B.

description: Not good for vegetarians. The spaghetti I had was bland and really expensive for such a small unexciting dish. That being said, great ambiance as a lunchtime downtown spot. I'd go back but wouldn't expect to be filled up with a delicious meal, as a vegetarian. I hear the cheese plates are good. Would come for a coffee or drink, and snacking.
author: Carolyn N.

description: Have to say. Never write reviews but this place knocked my socks off. Amazing food, so nice and put up with a late night large party super patiently. I can't get over the food though. Meat lovers -- run don't walk. Charcuterie on point and the trout dishes were madness.
author: Emily G.

description:
Trou Normand is a nice place for a weekend brunch, but I will not come back.
The food was good: The crab salad had great flavors, the scrambled egg were done just the right way, the Schnitzel was very good, especially the sauce on top and the crostata had a thin crust that worked very well with the fruit on top.
Service was a bit slow but reasonable.
The price, on the other hand was not. Trou Normand is very expensive (more than $80 for 2 brunch dishes, 2 coffees and one dessert). You can find great places in San Francisco for brunch that cost way less and are still as enjoyable as Trou if not more.
author: Isaac K.

description:
Love the space! The minimalist-Deco high-ceilinged interior is stylish, but not cold. And the back patio is fantastic! 

The breadth of the house-made charcuterie selection is also impressive. Unfortunately, the execution on it and the rest of the menu is way too fat heavy. 

We did the chef's choice 4 meat charcuterie and were shocked at how fatty it was. We either had to try to tear off parts of fat or just not eat it. 

We also ordered the goat, but it too was fat fat fat. Don't get me wrong, my 200+ cholesterol count attests that I love me some fat, but this was just too much. It was chewy and overwhelming. 

The veggies were super tasty (the artichoke hearts and grilled alliums (onions)), though were also drowning in fatty sauces. 

Not a fan.
author: Sean B.

description:
First impression at the hostess table was off: I've never seen a hostess sitting down to receive guests. The hostess shouldn't be sitting at all during dinner time. 

The waitress didn't show up at our table until 10 mins after we got seated. She was nice, but a little off. This is our first time dining there. We were expecting some introduction or guidance on their specialty. 

The napkins were a major turnoff too. They shed. You can see how poor the quality is. 

I think this is a place for HH, not really for dinners.
author: Danielle W.

description:
It's still true...the service is VERY slow. Although the staff is pleasant and try to be helpful, our brunch took over 2.5 hours!  And we only had burgers, French toast, and a small charcuterie sampler plate.  The restaurant wasn't too crowded either. 

The French toast tasted one dimensional because it was drowned in maple syrup, I didn't pick up any savory tones from the egg/bread.  The 2 pate selections were delicious (both were country style) but the cured meats were a bit bland.  The ice cubes were so large that the glass of lemonade we ordered was probably filled only 1/3 with lemonade. 

Overall, we probably won't come back again.
author: C L.

description:
Not for the faint of heart, this place is a marinade of meaty smells. In fact, I'm often the face looking in the window in the morning, as the kitchen crew are breaking down huge portions of meat and bone. The aroma of simmering stocks is heavenly, should be distilled to a cologne.

My lamb and olive sausage sandwich was delightful, if a little small and a little too heavy on the salt. Some chips would have been nice. And mustard. 

Drinks are a bit twee and out of character for a fine meat purveyor, I think.

But all in all, worth another visit or two as there's nothing a little thought and a bit of effort couldn't fix.
author: Mutant O.

description: Fantastic place for a Sunday Brunch. Enjoyed the Bratwurst plate with poached eggs and a mustard based hollandaise sauce to die for. My wife ordered all sides with eggs, bacon & potatoes and of course we had mimosas. Because we were celebrating our anniversary they gave us a complimentary dessert. The key lime ice cream sandwich was wonderful. Highly recommend this place.
author: Chris B.

description:
A lot  I tried was pretty tasty, but the overall experience doesn't fully live up to their prices. 

It is Financial district, so you expect a FiDi tax. It still hurts though. I do appreciate that they factor in service into their final prices, so you do not have to tip for service, but even with that considered  I found the food expensive. 

The roast pork and the duck were pretty tasty, but the portions were small and because you only get the protein you need to order the (also expensive) sides to make it a full meal. The guanciale and almond Brussels sprouts were not bad. Their arancini were good. Simple, but well made. I enjoyed the two cocktails I tried. The lemon tart was just OK, but I enjoyed their chocolate pot de creme with toffee.

I was somewhat let down by their service. Our servers were friendly, but for such a swanky looking place, service was not as sharp as I would have liked. 

I would suggest coming here for drinks and an evening snack rather than a full on dinner.
author: Augusto T.

description:
Popped in for a quick dinner and this place is a delight. Service was amazing. I didn't find anything I liked on their cocktail menu
So I asked if the bartender can whip up
Something vodka based....he did! The first drink wasn't that great, I was going to drink it anyway Coz I felt bad about having to ask to make
Me another one, they were fine with it and would rather have me enjoy my drink. We ordered the pork belly, Monterey squid with yogurt and the parpadelle.  Everything is delicious! I'm coming back for sure.
author: Gia C.

description:
Came here with a couple of friends before my birthday party somewhere else and the dinner food was great.  The pork chop done like a steak is a must have. The drink of choice is the old fashioned!  

Dinner 4 stars!

Then... I came back here for breakfast and they need to do some work on it.  The menu is miniscule and confusing because they put the entrees mixed in with the side dishes.  You'd think beef sausage patties for $12 might be an entree, but it really is just two tiny patties that taste like hamburger. Tomato toast was also just sliced tomatoes on toast which was overpriced. I did get a stewed pork dish that had grilled lettuce on it that was much tastier.  I'd suggest tightening up the breakfast menu to be more cohesive.  The menu listed on Yelp is out of date.

Breakfast - 2.5 stars
author: David N.

description: Cool vibe. Beautiful and delicious French inspired charcuterie and cheeses. Perfect for a mid-afternoon snack when out with friends.
author: Carla H.

description:
Some amazing cured meats. Lovely decor and even a moderate size courtyard out back where they had set up a tent and heaters. 

Of course, try the lardo. Basically cured animal fat thinly sliced. Quite the delicacy. In general, if you love charcuterie platters, this place will be quite a treat. 

This place also seems to have a bustling happy hour scene as well
author: Jimmy H.

description:
I really wanted to like this place because they had such a large charcuterie selection, but every course was a disappointment. 

1) chefs selection charcuterie board of 8
First off be aware that the chefs selections are ONLY meats, not cheeses.  I would say the only thing that was good on here was the salami selections - squid ink one was a bit salty. But the Lardo and pancetta - STRAIGHT up fat.  It's not even right to be able to order this. But hey if you're a fan I won't complain.

2) entrees
Tagliatelle - it was probably 80% sausage and 20% pasta and the sausage was wayyyyyy too salty. And because the sausage was the majority of the dish needless to say I ate about 20% of this dish.
Lamb chops - WAY TOO RARE. I get that lamb chops are supposed to be eaten rare but it was literally burnt on the outside and raw on the inside .. No thanks
Pork chops - again 50% of this hunk of meat was FAT!! Seriously?? Not okay, what a rip off
Eggplant side - tell me why this was bitter.  The yogurt and herbs tasted nice but as soon as you started enjoying it a bitter taste sets in.

3) desserts
Apple mint ice cream sandwich - no not worth it. The dark chocolate outside and the weird minty fruit ice cream does NOT go.
